<Author>ehf5
<Content>Solid Choice My husband and I were trying to decide between this hotel and the El San Juan. We picked the Caribe only because the reviews about bed bugs at the ESJ freaked us out. We visited the ESJ and the Ritz for dinner and some gambling while we were there, so here are my thoughts about our decision. The lobby of the Caribe looks like a typical Hilton--it's clean and spacious but nothing spectacular. We were there from Sunday night-Wednesday night and never saw a crowd at the bar. One night there was quite decent music, though. A frequent business guest told us that the place gets crowded on Thursdays when there's a good band, but...The El San Juan's lobby is very ornate and was very busy when we were there on a Tuesday night. With several busy bar areas, the hotel felt much more social and festive. On the other hand, the large number of people could well have been a turn-off--there were what can only be described as packs of young teenagers wandering around looking for something to do, and one or two clumps of obnoxious Americans. It was not restful, but it was a lot of fun. The tiny lobby of the Ritz was 100% deserted at 11 PM. The lobby bar appeared to be closed.As for the pools, the Caribe's pool looks beautiful as you approach it from the lobby, but from anywhere else in the pool area, it's not particularly stunning. It was sometimes hard to find seats even though it wasn't busy. It was always very clean, though, and there was never a crowd at the bar or restaurant, so service was fast and friendly. The beach is the only private one in the San Juan area, so it felt very safe for small families, but it was very small and you certainly couldn't take a walk down the beach. The pool at the El San Juan really impressed us. We sort of wished we were staying there, with the oversized loungers, umbrellas, and multiple pool-side areas. It looked very glamorous, but we weren't there during the day.The pool at the Ritz was gorgeous, with stone lions spouting water, but it had the same kind of seats as the Hilton.Our room at the Hilton was also quite typical--clean, spacious, and newly renovated. There was a small bar area and a desk in the room. The bathroom didn't have a tub--it had a beautiful shower. Nothing spectacular, but quite nice. Some thoughts about staying at the Hilton: It has easier access to Old San Juan than the other hotels, and we spent almost every night there. Cab rides to town cost $10-$14, and to Isla Verde (the Ritz or ESJ) from the Hilton cost up to $20. The ride into town was well worth it. At the hotel, the food is very expensive, even for resort standards. $8 beers and $15 mudslides get a little ridiculous. None of the restaurants at the Caribe offered reasonably priced food, and we never bothered eating at any of them. Advice: use the Hilton Honors Executive Lounge for breakfast, enjoy lunch at the hotel or hit Subway, and take advantage of the convenience store for sodas, snacks, and even some drinks (pass the tapas bar, turn right toward the Subway on the corner). Definitely go into Old San Juan at night. We took the tour to the rainforest with the extended hike to the waterfall and really liked it. Our tour guide (Yogi) was so good that random people from other tours kept trying to join us. He talked the whole time but was incredibly interesting and covered a lot of different kinds of information. If they'll tell you, try to find out when he's the guide. He's worth it. Overall, with the proximity to Old San Juan, the private beach, and the VERY friendly staff, the Caribe was a good option for us. We would try the El San Juan next time if we don't hear about any more bugs, but we might regret moving farther from town.On Old San Juan: There are basically two main areas--Calle Fortaleza that's quite trendy with Dragon Fly (very good!) and the sister restaurants; and Calle San Sebastian that's supposedly more bohemian. With so many places to choose from, it was much more fun to go there for the night than to eat in the hotel. Food wasn't necessarily inexpensive, but at least we got to browse the different vibes and go bar hopping a bit. The first night we really planned, but then we just went into town and walked around until we found something we liked. We ate later (around 8-8:30) and sometimes had to wait 20 minutes for a table. Earlier in the evening seemed more crowded with families for dinner. If places will take a reservation, get the concierge to make one for you before you head over. If they don't, don't worry. Our favorite places in Old San Juan were Ostra Cosa for dinner and Nuyorican Cafe for music and dancing. Ask the concierge. All of the restaurants had very slow service, but we weren't in a hurry. Dragon Fly was very good all-round and is fun and funky inside. Baru had great menu items but the food wasn't that well cooked. Their mojitos were good, so we wished we had gone back to Ostra Cosa and just had drinks at Baru. We also ate at the Italian place in the ESJ, which wasn't great. The service was earnest and friendly, and the decor was elegant, but the food was mediocre. Overall, there were a lot of places with personality, which was fun.  
<Date>Feb 22, 2008

7	2(night):1	64(spend):1	93(easy):1	159(access):1	177(san):1	477(hilton):1	617(juan):1	

<Author>1BennBenn
<Content>Great and very relaxing We recently spent four nights at the Caribe Hilton (Feb 17 to 21, 2008). It was fantastic. The room was large, clean, and comfortable with a great view over the ocean and the nearby Hotel Normandie. The fancy drinks were good. If you don't want to spend a lot on food, there is a Puerto Rican sandwich-breakfast store across the street, and a subway next to that. The bus to Old San Juan is 75 cents (change only, no dollars) and takes about 10 minutes. The walk to Condado is about 20 minutes. The package we got from Hilton was about $2000 for round trip airfare from DC and 4 nights at the hotel. If we had waited until the last minute we could have gotten it for about $1500 or $1600.The Hotel offered a trip to the rain forest for $53 per person that took six hours and was lots of fun. A very entertaining tour guide named Yogi took us. Stopped at at little Puerto Rican greasy food place (as Yogi called it) that was good, and cheap.If you are a Hilton Honors member (or maybe even if you aren't) you can have a complimentary continental breakfast on the 2d floor of the Hilton Honors Tower that is good.  
<Date>Feb 22, 2008

<Author>tonynelson
<Content>wonderful resort hotel This has to be the best hotel in San Juan in terms of overall vacation experience. The hotel has a nice private beach with a protected swimming cove, great workout area, nice pools, several good restaurants, attractive common areas and incredible views.The hotel is located 5 minutes from old San Juan, 5 minutes from Candado and 10-15 from Isla Verde and the airport, so it's easy to get anywhere. Most cab rides were $10-12 with Isla Verde and the airport coming in at $19-20.I read some reviews complaining about the food prices and room quality. While there were definitely some cosmetic problems with the room, I don't understand the negativity. Overall it was a nice room with a flat panel, huge shower and plenty of storage. And who cares about the room really? I'm sure the Ritz has much nicer rooms, but their beach is public and is nowhere near as nice as the Hilton's.As for the food prices, yes they are pretty steep. But my wife and I went to dinner at a lot of different hotels and I can tell you that $9 for a pina colada isn't so steep when compared to $14 for the same drink down the road. My advice: Make sure that you budget more for food/drinks than you expect.My other advise is to bring plenty of sunscreen. If you run out and have to buy it at the sundries shop, those pina coladas will start looking really cheap.We'll be going back to this hotel--probably next time with the kids.  
<Date>Feb 15, 2008

<Author>Tim2458
<Content>Decent Room, Overpriced Food, Nice Pool This was my second visit to the Caribe. My first, before TripAdvisor existed, ended rather abruptly when an explosion and fire knocked out the power system and the staff handled the situation very poorly. I only came back this time because of a conference held at the hotel.My room, in the old main building, was renovated compared to my last visit, but the finishes were off a bit , mostly in the bathroom -- rusty shower head, cheap bathroom door, sloppy paint job. Still, my oceanview room was not bad overall and the bed was very comfy. The bathrooms have Crabtree and Evelyn toiletries. The TV carried the major networks' NYC affiliates, which was good for me. The Internet service was out half the time I was there. I brought a broadband card for my computer. I'm glad I did. Besides the spotty Internet service, I felt the $14.95 a day charge for it was ridiculous. Don't forget your cell phone, or you'll pay an arm and a leg for the phone service.Since the Caribe charges a 15 percent resort fee per day -- yes, that's 15 percent, not $15 -- the Internet service should have been included. What that 15 percent (which adds up when your room is $220 a night, a reduced conference rate) gets you are towels and a lounge chair on the beach or at the pool, and the use of the fitness center, which has seen better days and is in severe need of a renovation. I did not use the spa and the spa restaurant (more of a food bar) was closed when I went there. Dinner for one at Morton's came to more than $100, and could have been much more. I stayed away from the other restaurants at the hotel and satisfied myself with coffee and a danish from Starbucks in the morning. Conference meals were pretty good. For lunch, I took the public bus (Route 1, just a five minute walk from the hotel and only 50 cents each way) into old San Juan. Try the courtyard restaurant at the Hotel El Convento for a tasty and relatively inexpensive meal in a nice setting.The beach is actually a lagoon, nice, but beware of rocky areas. There is a man-made reef that keeps the big waves out, but a strong off-shore breeze brought some waves in despite the break, which I liked. On some days the water was clear. On others, debris washed in. The pool was very nice. There is now a small additional pool near the conference rooms, for use by guests in the newer tower.Housekeeping was good some days and forgetful on others, not leaving wash cloths or refills of shampoo or bath gel. The staff was generally friendly. Upon check-in, they tell you they will add $1 a day for a charity they support unless you say no. They forgot to add that fee, but put on others, including a porterage fee and a housekeeping fee that the hotel insisted be paid by our conference attendees. Since I carried my own bag, the porterage fee really irked me, especially since nothing was said about this fee in advance. I saw it on my bill the morning I checked out and they refused to remove it when I complained. There is a staff person just outside the doors or ramp leading to the beach and pool to keep non-hotel guests out, but I guess I looked the part and was never asked to show my room key or the card that must be shown when charging food to your room.I did not go to the casinos, but they are a short walk away in hotels along the Condado. There is also a casino in the Sheraton (formerly a Wyndham) near the bus and ferry terminals in Old San Juan. There are plenty of shops in Old San Juan. Be aware there is a 5.5 percent sales tax on clothing.I doubt I will stay here again. I've been to Puerto Rico many times and each hotel in San Juan or Dorado had its flaws. The nicest place at which I stayed was actually a wonderful guest house on the island of Vieques off the west coast of the main island, reachable by ferry from Fajardo or plane from San Juan. It's called Casa LaLanchita and owned by a family from New York State named McHoul. It is a beautiful facility on the ocean and their hospitality is unmatched. One problem, though. It's become so popular, it is usually booked solid during the season.  
<Date>Feb 8, 2008

<Author>Guidor
<Content>Over-priced but Efficient My wife and I have just returned from a week's stay at the Caribe Hilton in San Juan PR , paying a convention rate which still was quite expensive. Every additional item was charged and the restaurants' meals  drinks were extortionate - so thanks to previous travellers who suggested the convenient Subway on the corner nearby. It is often worthwhile getting a cab into Old San Juan ($10 to $11 each way) to sample the numerous restaurants there and the vibrant street scene (a festival on the Sunday celebrating San Sebastian and noisy Birthday celebrations).The room was comfortable and the front desk did move us at our request due to the dull view across a cigarette butt strewn roof we had from the third floor room initially allocated. One bright spot was the pride in his job shown by Augustus who took care of the pool area near the tropical gardens. It was kept absolutely pristine and it was clear how much he cared for the area and the hotel guests who used it.  
<Date>Jan 31, 2008

<Author>rosette_8
<Content>Wonderfull!!! I had to write a review as we were almost scared off of this hotel by what others had written.We loved it! We had a great room with amazing views (1565). It must have been newly remodeled and it was extremely nice. Very clean, comfortable and the shower.....amazing! The beds were incredibly comfortable.Everyone working at the hotel was wonderful and polite. The pool and ocean (beach) setting were wonderful and allowed you to sit at the pool and then swim in the ocean which was just as close as the pool. The pool was very clean which I am not sure how with the ocean and sand so close.Also, when we were there, there weren't many children since it wasn't anyones break, but the kids there were VERY well behaved and enjoyable to be around. No screaming Mom and Dads at tired little ones.We were there with a conference and every one of us (6 couples)had a great experiences. Even those with older rooms had no problem.Only issue would be that you couldn't charge the things in the stores to your room. That would have been nice instead of going back to your room to get money.We want to go back with the kids sometime!

<Author>aggupta
<Content>Average Hotel The Caribe Hilton is pretty average and like any other hotel. It is very touristy. There are a ton of Americans that stay there along with a Starbucks and a Morton's Steakhouse so don't expect to get a local experience by staying here. The pool is full of children so I would not recommend this place for a romantic get away. The gym is very small although the staff there were very helpful and able to recommend scenic routes to jog along the beach. On a positive note, the walk to Old San Juan takes about 25 minutes (about 2 miles). There is a beautiful park on the way and it is great to wander into town if you walk along the beach. On the whole, the Hilton is a clean place to stay, but don't expect to experience Puerto Rico at this hotel.  
<Date>Jan 22, 2008

<Author>tarheeljd
<Content>Decent Hilton I stayed at the Hilton Caribe on business. Would not recommend for families. You would be much better off staying at the Southern side of the PR. My understanding is the resorts are much nicer - including the Hilton Resort property.The Hilton is ok - says it has been renovated. I am a frequent business traveler so my standards are very high. The rooms were fine - they were clean, nice tv, etc. I stayed on the Executive floor - so I had acccess to the Executive Lounge - was a nice upgrade.The biggest issue I saw with the resort was the lack of a real beach. There is a small beach but it can get really crowded.This would be a fine place to stay if you were there for one night but I would not want to have my family there for the week.The staff was great and very pleasant.

<Author>grapdad
<Content>Good Experience I am a Hilton Diamond HHonors member, so stay at Hilton whenever I can. Caribe Hilton is one of the first Hilton's in the chain, built in 1947, and continually upgraded. It probably needs it again. Our room, on the Ocean, was, as was mentioned by others, not available until 4PM, which is the guaranteed check-in time. From 2PM until 4PM, I was told our room would be avaiable in 20 Minutes. This occured 4 times. We were finally given an alternate room, which did not have as good a view as originally ordered, but was OK. Room was clean, and the new Hilton comfort bed sheets were very nice. Bed was very comfortable. Service was very nice, and the beach was awesome! The poolside food was vertually inedible, soggiy cold sandwiches, and watered drinks. Having said that, I would go back. but please see my review of the Condado Plaza.

<Author>IrishmomTX
<Content>Weather Fantastic We traveled to the Caribe Hilton 12/27/07 to 1/2/08. Waited as expected until 4 PM to receive our rooms, however hotel did make it easy to store luggage so that grounds and pools (changing rooms available) could be explored. Received connecting rooms which was nice we were travelling with our two children in their early twenties. View was only fair could see water, pools etc by but hotel lower roof interferred with the view. Rooms were fine, beds were very comfortable. Hotel restaurants are extremely pricey. Service at Olas Health restaurant was outrageously slow. Quick lunch or breakfast alternative was the Starbucks (sandwiches  salads) or the Subway at the end of the drive. Small cafeteria at the end of the drive was closed for the holidays. Was extremely impressed with what the hotel had to offer for families with young children however might recommend Isla Verde area for families with teens or twenties. Cab ride to old San Juan was reasonable. El Morro and Bacardi tour, and Paseo de Princessa were worth the time. I was disappointed in rainforest tour as no birds or critters of any type were visible. Parrot Club in Old San Juan was excellent, also La Bombonera for breakfast. Had an enjoyable New Year's Eve at Senor Frogs.

<Author>HhonorsFan
<Content>Don't Believe Bad Reviews....This Hotel is Great!!!! This hotel is a true resort on beautiful island (Puerto Rico). I would not believe the bad reviews. This hotel was great. I was at the hotel over winter break and the hotel was happening. The pools are great, service is great, and the hotel property is great. I would say that if you could get a rate below 250 it is definitely worth it. The location is a okay at best, but it is no big deal. There is a subway sandwich shop on the property and a convenience store too. Cabs are expensive in San Juan and based on zone. A 4 minute cab to old san juan is 11 dollars and Condanado is 15 ( I walked to Condanado in about 10 minutes) and don't even bother going to Isla Verde for 19 dollars. I had access to the Executive Lounge which was great. I recommend going to the lounge on floor 9 of the main building instead of going to the lounge in the Hhonors tower. They have fridges full of water and all types of pop that are free all day. I took the drinks and put them in the fridge that is in the room. I wasn't with little kids, but it is a fantastic hotel for kids. Plenty of shallow water in the pool area and the beach is protected by rocks, which limits the high waves that most of san juan sees. The beach is fantastic, not many waves, but a nice little stretch (especially compared to other hotels in San Juan). The rooms are a little above standard, but not extremely fancy. I went to the Old San Juan Hotel and Ritz and was not impressed. Those hotels are for people who want to tell people that I stayed at the Ritz or I stayed at the InterContinental. Lunch by the pool and drinks are expensive, but what do you expect, its a hilton not a Motel 6. I am not a little kid, but the coolest thing at the hotel is the fish feeding pier. They give you bread to throw in the ocean, and you get to see many different types of fish (size and color) without having to go snorkeling or scuba diving. I did not use the spa, but it did look nice (but expensive...what do you expect). The workout facility in the Spa (which if free for guests) is fantastic and overlooks the ocean. So the moral of the story...don't believe the bad reviews and if you get a good rate don't hesitate to book it. The hotel doesn't have a casino, but the candanado hotel which is about a 10 minute walk and the Marriot which is about 15 minute walk have casinos (I'd go to the Marriott...I won Big). Keep in mind this is San Juan not Las Vegas. A couple restaurants that I definitely recommend: Parrot Club (Old San Juan/Local Cuisine/Average entree 20-30), Dragon Fly (Old San Juan/Fusion between Asian and Latino Cuisine). I could write another couple pages, but I hope you get the point. This property is fantastic...if you get a good rate book it and don't worry about the bad reviews. Keep in mind most people only review a hotel when they have a great time or a terrible experience. As you could tell, I had a great time and can't wait to go back.P.S. Don't freak out about the weather forecast before you go. I checked weather.com and it said rain for the whole week I was down there and it was sunny 99% of the time. I think they just predict rain at 50% everyday so they wont be wrong.  
<Date>Jan 8, 2008

<Author>TejasJuez
<Content>Great for kids, but in need of some remodel I cannot imagine a better hotel to travel to with kids. The pool area, the private beach, the games to borrow, the activities, bouncy things, fish to feed, etc. etc. This place is just beautiful beyond words. That being said, there are different types of accomodations in this massive resort, and the rate you pay and your Hilton HHonors status do seem to dictate the type of accomodation you get. We stayed in Room 515 in December 2007 for our fourth stay at the property. 515 is in the older, main part of the hotel. There are at least 3 other sections -- the Towers, the Garden Suites, and the Lagoon Villas. We have stayed only in the Towers and the main building. The main building the last 2 times we've stayed, has been in need of some remodeling. The grout around the tile and tub was cracked and black, and the tub did not turn off all the way. The wooden bathroom door and trim were starting to deteriorate from the moisture. And the tile in the bathroom was a pale mauve circa 1958, I'd guess. But everything in the room worked. The bathroom ventilation is a bit odd because you can hear people talking through it as if they were in your bathroom, but you can hear it only when you are in the bathroom. The bottom of the tub in 515 was also starting to separate from the floor, which gave a feeling of standing on a waterbed when in the bathroom. So, the room wasn't great. But we didn't really care. The tower rooms are newer and in our experience are in better condition. A tip -- book online at the Hilton website and check into the bounceback rate. It includes a huge buffet breakfast, which normally costs over $20.00 per person.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2008

<Author>cowboyhunter
<Content>we made the right choice! I just returned from a family vacation at the Caribe Hilton. I feel obligated to write a review, as I poured over the prior trip advisor reviews so intently as I evaluated where we should stay. This was a wonderful choice! The beach, pool area and grounds of this property are beautiful. The hotel itself is very pretty, and seemed to be well maintained. Other reviews had noted differences between more recently updated rooms, I heard and saw nothing of it. The staff was very accomodating and pleasant. We traveled with other families with teenagers, and I will note, that there is a lack of night-life here. We did take cabs to Isle Verde, Old San Juan and Condado for dinner and gambling. The trade off for staying at the Caribe and venturing out in the evenings is well worth it. The other hotels did not compare. The Caribe was by far the best choice.

<Author>Lin91
<Content>Don't waste your time or money on this place! We booked an oceanview studio villa at the Caribe Hilton for three nights (Dec. 27-30) 10 months in advance considering this is a popular travel time and we wanted to make sure we had a nice room. When we arrived they checked us in and made no mention of any changes to our stay, but when we got to our room it was not an oceanview at all and it was nothing more than a standard hotel room that did not at all resemble a villa. The view was of the building under construction next door and and there was not even a peek of the ocean. We immediately called downstairs and informed them that this was not the type of room we had reserved and the front desk offered no explanation as to why they had given us this room, they simply said they would have to call us back. Well, 15 minutes later we got a call back and they offered a reduction of $100/night and the possibility of moving us to an oceanview, but we would have to wait until 4:00pm the next day to see if there would be one available. Considering we were paying over $500/night for nothing more than a cramped and worn standard room overlooking construction and the parking garage we turned down their offer and asked to speak to the hotel manager. He did return our call about 20 minutes later and proceeded to tell us that the computer showed that we had not booked an oceanview room. We informed him that we had our confirmation with us and we would be happy to show it to him. At this time, he cut the rate in half (still overpriced as we checked on the hotel website and it showed they had oceanview rooms available in the main hotel for the same price!!). I should also mention that my husband is Hilton Honors Gold, so I would have expected a little more effort up front to remedy the situation. To top it all off, the manager on duty in the villa tower was rude when we later went downstairs and asked that the rest of our reservation be cancelled because we were going back to the Hampton Inn  Suites next to the airport (great staff and beautiful rooms) where we had stayed the previous three nights.  
<Date>Dec 31, 2007

<Author>nyfamilyLongIsland
<Content>Far surpassed my expectations I was a bit nervous about the Caribe due to the mixed reviews, but it was wonderful. We are a family with two teenagers, travelled with two other families. Everyone had a great time, mostly because of the fabulous property with real resort feel, the friendly staff, and the activities. The pool and beach area were very spread out and inviting, as was the lobby. We all enjoyed activities such as bingo and volleyball, but mostly relaxed by the pool and enjoyed the beautiful ocean views. The only negative aspectof the hotel was the lack of casino and somewhat remote location. This was not a big deal as we took a short taxi ride each night to check out restaurants, hotels, and casinos that were all very nearby. Although the condado and isle verde hotels were more hopping at night, we felt that the resort feel at caribe made it more relaxing and welcoming to families. We did not eat in any of the restaurants other than the breakfast buffet which was great. We also took advantage of the towers snacks in the afternoon which was perfect for after pool and before late dinner. There is a bodega steps from the hotel for snacks, etc, and also a subway, which was fine for the kids for one lunch. We did stay in towers rooms which were very nice, newly renovated for sure, great bathroom, but small rooms. It was fine b/c we didn't spend too much time in room at all. I did take a quick look at one of the regular rooms, and it looked fine as well. Overall, we had a great time and would definitely return to the caribe hilton.

<Author>johnboy53Durham_NC
<Content>Pretty good pre-Christmas visit Four of us made a three night trip to the Caribe Hilton the week before Christmas (2007). This was our 4th family stay there (and Dad had had several business visits in addition). Last year we were particularly impressed by the Executive Level lounge, where we enjoyed unlimited alcoholic beverages each evening. The hors d'oevres and desserts/coffee were also free. This was a significant factor in our returning to the Caribe. However, unannounced the hotel has changed its policy. Now there is a cash bar - with a barman - for a couple of hours only each evening. (Actually, they won't take cash, only charges to your room). Admittedly, at $3 for wine and (I think) $4 for spirits it's still a good deal compared with other bars in the hotel. However, it was disappointing. Presumably the free bar was felt to be open to abuse, costing the hotel more than it was prepared to pay for the goodwill. The hotel has a stated policy of not allowing children under 14 into the Executive Lounge. They need to enforce this. Frequently, small children were allowed to run around; one we saw burned her fingers playing with the steam option on the expresso machine. We are not against small children, but this lounge is not a suitable place for them to play. We found the hotel rather quiet: other guests opined that aggressive competition from new super-resort hotels (eg the Conquistador) is hurting the Caribe (and the Normandie Hotel next door appeared almost empty, as judged by the paucity of lit rooms at night). We ran into a demonstration one morning against the villa development on Condado: apparently some of the new building, incl the Caribe's, has encroached on the protected Old Fort site. (We didn't expect to run into a political demo against our hotel!). Overall, our stay met our expectations. Very low key and relaxing. Things we'd like improved? The infinity pool that is the centerpiece of the hotel recreation area is colder than the ocean in December. How much would it cost the hotel to heat it up a bit for its guests, who are paying plenty for the privilege of swimming in cold water? They might actually recoup the cost in swim-up patrons to the pool bar! (currently, no one is brave enough to endure to cold water to sit on the pool side of the bar). Also, get rid of the guys posted at the entrance to the pool area who check to make sure only guests get through. We encountered several who insisted we go away and return with room keys. Especially when the hotel is quiet, this comes across as tacky and unfriendly. If they insist on doing this, give the guests colored wrist bands or similar, instead.  
<Date>Dec 26, 2007

<Author>jacllyynn
<Content>Arrived with low expectations, and left impressed. After reading the reviews on this site, I was extremely disappointed when I found out my friend arranged for us to stay at the Caribe Hilton. I arrived at the hotel with very low expectations, expecting a has been hotel with old, dirty rooms. To my surprise and delight, my stay at the Caribe was absolutely wonderful! While the hotel was not as polished as other hotels I have stayed in, what it lacked, it made up for in atmosphere. The hotel has a very carribbean/tropical feel as the hotel's buildings blend with the outdoors. In fact, the lobby and many parts of the hotel are partially outdoors. We booked one of the cheaper ones, but upon arrival asked to stay in the new, renovated Honors Towers that I'd read so much about. The towers feel like their own hotel as they have their own separate lobby/check-in area. The room was very, very nice for the price. Room was extremely clean, nicely furnished, with a large marble bathroom (with rain head shower). There was a balcony overlooking Old San Juan and a partial view of the beach and ocean. We were told they could only give us a city view, so we were pleasantly surprised. The room included a flat screen tv hanging on the wall, a desk, and an extra chair. There was also a small fridge. The room was of decent size, but I thought the closet was too small, even for only 2 people. We didn't pay for access to the executive lounge, but we were able to gain access since we were staying in the Honors Tower. We had a continental breakfast which consisted of a small selection of pastries, fruit, sandwiches, cereal, and drinks. What I loved about the hotel was how it blended with nature. The hotel grounds are large and nicely designed. Yes, it's true that the hotel grounds have seen better days (when we were there, they were in the process of building/updating the circular deck that jets out into the ocean), but honestly, the little bit of chipped paint, a few weeds, etc did not detract from the overall beauty of the hotel. When you step outside from the lobby and bar, the first thing you see is a little pond leading to a large pool, and then the ocean behind it. It looks as if you are just a step away from the ocean even when you are still in the lobby. Very picturesque. There is also a garden with a koi pond with lots of fish, some bridges, and a gazebo. I even saw a few swans in the water. There's another smaller pool by the garden as well. The man-made beach is clean, but somewhat small. However, we had no problems finding chaises, and there weren't that many people even on a weekend. Getting a drink on the beach was somewhat slow though. Our waiter took over 40 minutes to come back with our drinks. Other than that, since it's a man-made beach, the current is somewhat blocked off by the wall so the water is much calmer thant the beaches in Condado. Also, there is a hammock area, but I only saw 1 hammock. We didn't try any of the restaurants as we ate in Old San Juan, but the bar in the lobby was pretty good at night (lots of people). There is also a Starbucks in the lobby. The hotel's location isn't the greatest (far from San Juan, and other parts of the island), but it is very close to Old San Juan, which is about a 10-12 minute drive away (it's basically just down the street), and the main Condado area, which is literally a 3 minute drive away. Overall, I had a wonderful stay at the Caribe Hilton and would definitely come back if I'm in San Juan. I also had the pleasure of staying at the Marriott Stellaris in Condado and I can honestly say that while I loved the Marriott, I would choose the Caribe Hilton as it had a more resort feel, which I prefer.  
<Date>Dec 5, 2007

<Author>mpbucks
<Content>Did the trick... We just got back from a trip over Thanksgiving week. We had read a couple of the reviews, and I would say more-or-less that our experience was consistent with what the majority of people said, but we really liked the place.Room - we stayed on the executive floor  had an oceanfront room. The room itself was pretty new, very clean and overall we were pleased with it. Our only issue, which was a slight one, was that the oceanfront view overlooked the ocean but also overlooked the main entrance. It wasn't a big deal though as the view of the ocean  fort was pretty cool. Staying on the executive floor was worth it. They treated you pretty well and it was nice to have water  soft drinks whenever you it was open.Pool/Ocean - was very nice. There were plenty of chairs to choose from; the pool was clean; the ocean beach was private. All good things. The hot tub wasn't too hot though.Spa - we had the spa vacation, so it included all the spa had to offer. The spa itself was nothing to write home about (pretty bland), but the treatments were good  we were treated pretty well.Restaurants - Breakfasts - we had breakfast included in the spa vacation and the buffet was good. Decent selection  it seemed fresh. The knock would be that it was $23 per person, but if you are on a package that includes it, it doesn't matter  is worth it. Lunch - we ate everyday at the pool bar. The food was so-so at best and we never had great service. Dinner - we only ate at Morton's, and you really can't go wrong there. Beverages - all the beverages we had were very good, and we tried a fair amount, but they were a drop pricey. Not too bad as we've been places where they were worse, but at least they were good each time.Location - for us, this was a huge plus. We wanted to have a very relaxing vacation...and this was a great location for it. We went to visit a bunch of the other big hotels - and they are all right on top of each other with planes flying over them. This hotel was out of the main area, but very close to Old San Juan as well for a little sight seeing.One note - we booked the vacation on hilton.com. After booking I checked the site a few times to see what else was available. Each time, the price of the room dropped. We started out with just a breakfast package, but ended up with a Spa package on the executive floor for less $. Once we booked that, we still noticed the price dropped a few times. Each time, we called the hotel and they quickly adjusted our price.We would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone else looking.  
<Date>Nov 25, 2007

<Author>FrquntTrvlr
<Content>Go Somewhere Else (Especially With Children)! We thought the Villas would be perfect for our needs. The kitchen and separate rooms worked out fine; but, it was the basics that were neglected by this hotel. (Even if you don't have children read this message.) After calling twice, prior to arrival, to child proof the room (ie collect wires, etc), there were lamp, phone, clock wires everywhere--not even wound up. It made the room look sloppy and cheap. The rug was falling apart. We waited over three hours for a high chair that should have already been in the room. The crib was RUSTED AND CHIPPING PAINT!!! NONE of the three televisions had the basics: NO DVD player, NO on-demand movie service, NO basic movie channels (ie HBO, Showtime, etc). There was no honor-bar in any of the rooms. The fans were noisy. The shower doors were broken; causing water on the floor. The thermostats failed to work. THE SERVICE WAS TERRIBLE!!!!!! For the most part the staff was nice; but for the ones who chose to feign: No speak English. To top the time at the hotel off, on the last day we bought a slice of chocolate cake at the Starbucks only to learn, one bite into it already, that there was mold on the bottom side of the cake. GROSS!

<Author>BaltoBalto
<Content>Great pool/beach area What we liked about the hotel:The pool/beach area are very well kept and really nice (although, keep in mind that the beach isn't very wide). The hotel also has lots of games/toys for kids to play with (such as slides into the ocean, floaties, etc). The service is also fantastic -- everywhere, from the reception to the staff at the pool.What we didn't like about the hotel:We weren't at all impressed with the food (at the poolside bar and grill). On that note, there is a Starbucks onsite and a Subway and mini-mart (with snack food, drinks, etc) across the street from the hotel, which were convenient.The rooms really do need an upgrade. We had one room in the main wing, which was fairly run down (especially the bathroom). The other half of our group stayed in a room in the Honors tower -- that had clearly been upgraded and was a lot nicer.Spa:I got a massage at the spa. The massage itself was good, but I was unimpressed with the rest of the spa -- it was very bare bones and not at all luxurious (prices of services were on par with other spas I have been to) -- not quite the overall experience I had been looking forward to.Other:Location is pretty good -- a ten minute drive from Old San Juan. We were told that there is also a bus that you can take from outside the hotel to Old San Juan that is pretty convenient. And of course, there are lots of taxis. If you can get to it, eat at Old San Juan instead of the hotel; there are lots of really good/fun restaurants there.

<Author>shasta37
<Content>The food was good I went to P.R on labor day weekend with three girlfriends. We stayed at the Hilton which is near Old San Juan. We asked around, to friends/family, to get a nice place to stay and this was the hotel name that kept popping up. We also wanted to stay there because we heard they had a awesome seafood buffet, that included lobster, on Friday nights at a reasonable price. We had also heard that if you stay on the executive floor you get free continental breakfast and before dinner drinks(alcoholic) w/hors d'oeuvres. The person we, my friends and I, had talked to stayed there in Feb 07. We were planning our trip in June. We called the hotel to inquire how much more this would cost us  they informed us it would be an extra $60/person but they did not have any more rooms available w/that package. We then called our travel agent who called them and they did have those rooms available. We did not book them because she said it would be cheaper if when we went to ask to be upgraded and see if we could get it cheaper. We agreed.Day of arrival: We arrive at the airport and get a taxi. All of the taxi services are a certain price if you are traveling in the what is considered the tourist area so no matter how many people you have going to a location inside the tourist area it's one price, which isn't bad. It cost the three of us $20.50 to get to our hotel 15 minutes away. My other friend who came on a later flight, it cost her the same thing by herself. So we get to the hotel and are checking in and inquire about the executive suites. They inform us that they do not have those room available because they are being renovated. The seafood buffet is not available either because it was in the same location. We were heated because we had called a week ago and they said it was sold out! Althought they had restaurants on the grounds we had our minds set on seafood. We asked the concierge if there were another place to get a seafood buffet. He told us to get in a taxi and go to The Ritz Carleton. We go to the Ritz and although they did have a seafood buffet, it wasn't vast enough. It was the basics and no lobster. Our friend did tell us of an authentic spanish resteraunt to eat at once we were there and it is called El Jibarito in Old San Juan located at Calle Sol 280. You have to walk quite a way if you take the bus to Old San Juan, but the food was well worth it and the price could not be beat. That's another thing if you can take the bus wherever you can. The taxi rides take a toll on your pocketbooks after a while. The bus is .75 and the bus drivers speak english.We found that there really was nothing to do once there except go to Old San Juan and walk around. It's very nice with its cobblestone streets and the docking area where the cruise ships come in. There is also a Walgreens and Marshall's there and alot of knicknacks to be bought. We took the bus to the mall, which is like any other mall. We tried to get a taste of the nightlife, but there was none. A hotel person told us to go to a certain club in downtown, but it was burned down. A waste of cab fare--two ways! The Hilton is away from other hotels so if you want to be around something don't stay there. It's more of a family or lovers atmosphere. The rooms also smelled moldy. They said we had a room with a view. The only view we had was of the construction going on another part of the hotel. Other than that it was okay. I wouldn't go there for another girls night out, but I would go for a lover's weekend.  
<Date>Sep 14, 2007

<Author>jhovee80
<Content>Not a great place for singles and adverturists! Ok...well, I choose this hotel based off of reviews that this hotel was fun and great and so on... and so on.... I took this trip by myself looking for a great week of rest, relaxation and a little bit of fun in between. Well, I definately got the rest and relaxation but I was missing a lot of the fun part. My room was beautiful with the most gorgeous marble/glass bathroom with a big ol' sexy shower, his and her sinks and a tinyitty bitty toilet pushed up in a corner behind the bathroom door! lol!! Other then the compromised space of the toilet, the bathroom was great, the room was a decent size and the bed was hell-a comfy!!! I had a room on a high floor overlooking the ocean and resort and let's not forget the dirty old building of the second hotel tower right smack in the middle of your view. And its nothing nice to look at. Trust me. I don't know whose bright idea it was to build a new tower of the hotel over looking the old one with teases of oceanview on your right and left sides. I feel sorry for the people that were below me on lower floors because I'm sure they got to experience more of the second tower then I did as they were not high enough to over look most of the building. So anyway, I had a spa package guys. The spa was great! I received a wonderful sweedish massage, manicure, pedicure and facial. But beware people...They charge tax for spa services. Now eventhough the spa services were included in my hotel price, I was still charged around $65 in taxes for the three days I was there. Definately caught me off guard.Now as far as dining and entertainment is concerned, they have a great little bar located in the lobby. Drinks are pricey but where are they not pricey? They have $3 beers during Happy Hour so make sure you rack up. There's also a swim up bar outside at the pool where you can order burgers and finger foods which are pretty tasty. That's only if you need a quick snack. I did not eat at Morton's Steak House because of the reviews that I read about the prices and quality. So for the most part, I ate in old San Juan a couple of times, therefore, I can't comment too much on the food at the hotel. I did receive complimentary buffet breakfast at the main hotel restaurant (sorry, I forgot the name) which was pretty good. You get omlets to order and an erray of breakfast treats. The pool and beach area are very nice with tons of places to set up lounge chairs. The beach is man made (what's with these resorts with man made beaches?) But if you're looking for a hotel with the watersports and outdoor activities, then this is not the place for you!! There's no casino, no water sports, no activites, nothing!! It kind of sucked! There was really nothing special about this hotel except for the over-priced food (which was nothing to brag about either when I did get a chance to eat there) and the hell-a comfy bed. If you want good food you're gonna have to take a $20 cab ride to Old San Juan. Aguasvivas was great! And word to the wise...... If you're gonna take a trip to the Bacardi Factory, call them first to make sure they are open. I was told by one of the travel agents at the hotel that the Bacardi factory was open 7 days a week eventhough the hotel only offered its tour on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday but you can take a 20 minute ride out there yourself and get a tour. SO.... that's what I did. I hopped in a cab and went over to the Bacardi Distillery just to find out that the place was closed!!! I paid $50 for a cab ride to nowhere!!!! Also, don't be fooled by the little boutiques at the hotel. If you walk right down the street there is a little bodega that sells souveniers for half the price. I racked up on those!! Overall, the hotel was nothing exciting. The people were pleasant, they all spoke English but it was like being in New York City with a tropical feel. Everyone is Amercianized. I even met a cab driver that used to live 5 minutes from me in New Jersey! Ha!! Great people though. But this hotel gets 2 thumbs down for activities, entertainment and night life.  
<Date>Aug 27, 2007

<Author>SerenityGirl
<Content>Beautiful We stayed for three nights on one of the Executive floors. This was well worth the extra $ since breakfast, lunch and snacks were free all day, plus cocktails were discounted. The hotel provided a free internet connection with printer too.The view was spectacular from all rooms, as far as I could tell. The pool was gorgeous and the beach was nice too. The hotel has put in an artificial reef on the beach which kept the water calm and made for some great snorkeling.The health club was very good too. I didn't try the spa.The down side is that the hotel is quite isolated from everything else. When I was there, quite a bit of construction was going on, which made walking to Condado Beach impossible. Not really the fault of the hotel. But, there aren't any restaurants within walking distance, so you either have to grab a cab to get something to eat or pay the prices at the hotel, quite expensive! The food was good though, even at poolside.Go to Isla Verde beach. Old San Juan is a shopper's paradise, but as I'm not into shopping, I didn't really enjoy it so much. We did take the horse and buggy ride which was nice. My favorite part was the snorkeling - it was like swimming in a tropical fish tank. Our teenagers got bored after a awhile.  
<Date>Aug 25, 2007

<Author>NCGoRedSox
<Content>Loved the Caribe! Just returned from a wonderful trip to Puerto Rico. When I go back, I'll stay at the Caribe Hilton. The hotel is clean, staff is awesome and the beach is breath taking! I stayed in room 440 and the view from the balcony is amazing. The restaurants at the hotel are expensive (just like any other hotel...) but, a $10 cab ride will take you to Old San Juan where you can find an abundance of places to eat. Also, directly across from the Hilton is a Mini Mart where you can get sodas, beer, liquor for the fridge in your room. There is also a Subway across the street, on the corner that has a good breakfast. Housekeeping staff are awesome! Our remote didn't work when we got there. Called downstairs and no one ever showed up. Left a $2 tip for housekeeping the next day with a note remote not working. When we returned our remote was fixed. Tip housekeeping and they will take really good care of you. At the bar, Victor (afternoons) and Vivianne (nights) are the best! There is only music Thurs - Sunday. A $19 cab ride will take you to the San Juan Hotel which has really good music in the lobby and for the younger crowd, an awesome club. Saul at the pool bar is great. Be prepared for $9 mixed drinks. The bacon cheeseburger at the pool bar is $9 with fries but, can be compared to a burger at nice resturant here. There is not an abundance of waiters walking around the pool/beach area but, the pool bar is less than a 1 minute walk from where you are. Overall, the Hilton is great and I will stay there again when I return to Puerto Rico!  
<Date>Aug 23, 2007

<Author>TheBigRagu95
<Content>Overall very good After reading these reviews for a couple months I figured I should foward my opinions for others to view as well. I went down for our 5 year wedding anniversary along with our wedding party and families (5 families, 10 adults, 12 kids). After speaking with the reservation manager we were upgraded to an ocean view room in the towers at the Garden view room price - all 5 families! The pool and beach were great for the kids. The food is expensive but that is what you get at a resort that is not all-inclusive. We loaded the fridge with breakfast and snack food from the minimart across the street and went over in Condado for some nice local Puerto Rican food a few times. The walk across the bridge really isn't that far and we did it with a stroller a as well. No casino is a bummer but it was known ahead of time. There are no waves but that should be known if you have read up a little. Rooms were small but clean. The shower and the beds are great but I wish the beds were a little bigger being we needed the rooms with two beds versus one King. The ENTIRE staff was very nice to us. They do not move quick, but were helpful if it was with the stroller or getting a shuttle to San Juan. We booked a few excursions on our own and saved some money - the Bio Bay in Farjado is a must! If you do not want to Kayak it call Captain Suarez as he is the only one allowed in the bay with a boat. The Rainforrest is beautiful and you must make it to La Mina waterfall.Enjoy your time there!  
<Date>Aug 17, 2007

<Author>zacaramarketing
<Content>You know, not so bad! Quite a bit of mixed reviews here. I am a long time Hilton customer and have stayed at many properties around the world. This was really not as bad as people make it out to be. Sure it is old but it is clean and there are people working all day long to keep it up and looking good. It could use some sprucing up but it was just fine for a long weekend or so. We were there 4 nights.Despite what others have said the beach is pretty darn nice. Clean, private and no, there are not rocks everywhere. We even saw a nice array of fish while snorkeling by the break rocks about 50 yards off shore.The pool is also very nice, even when crowded there is a chair to be found and plenty of space in the pool to relax.One thing that is true is that it is expensive to eat and drink here but why wouldn't you go off campus to Condado or OSJ to do that?Our room was nice with a large bathroom. I also understand some rooms have yet to be refurbished but they all will be in time. The people on staff were also as pleasant as they could be, except for one Concierge that had a bit of an attitude.All in all the place was just fine for a few day Caribbean getaway and I would go back. It is an old place that is kept up, keep that in mind and go enjoy!

<Author>Nestiny
<Content>Beautiful We stayed at the Caribe Hilton from August 12 to August 15. I did not pay for this trip so I can not complain about prices. Although I do know that many of the restaurants and drinks are pretty expensive. But delicious.Everyone was extremely helpful and to your service. No complaints. If you needed something they were there for you immediately. The grounds and rooms were super clean and spacious. We stayed in the Lagoon Villas which had 2 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, full kitchen, and living room. Absolutely gorgeous. Very well kept. I would definately reccommend the Catimiran trip. This is an all day relaxation experience. You are served food and drinks all day on the boat and stop at a deserted island to bathe in the sun or snorkel. Following that...you are brought to a deep sea reef where the schools of fish surround you. (Bring an underwater camera)We also booked a tour to see the Yungue rainforest with extended hike to La Mina falls. Gus was our tour guide...he was the BEST!!! If you hike through the forest and do not go in the waterfalls then you are crazy!!!!! It is so fresh you must drink some. Perfect. Loquillo beach and Old San Juan are also musts. All in all... the hotel was splendid and would go back in a jiffy. Bit expensive....but very nice. Say Hola to Pancho and Coco (the birds in the lobby) for me.!!!  
<Date>Aug 16, 2007

<Author>daveb84
<Content>It's slipped since last time I have stayed at the Caribe Hilton twice before, but not in about 6 or 7 years. While the property still looks terrific, the rooms and views are wonderful, and the endless construction seems to be over, it's the staff that's slipped...dramatically. (Also, the Tommy Bahama store is gone in favor of some tacky clothing shop). Upon check-in (at the Hilton Honors Gold Members line) I was treated with indifference. I had time to kill at the bar (couldn't hit the pool: pouring rain and no luggage, anyway!) and the bar staff was cordial at best. Still without a change of clothes to go out to dinner, I had to eat in the bar/lounge area. My waitress was slow, grouchy, and also indifferent to my COLD sandwich. Things in this regard did improve somewhat over the several days I was there, but it wasn't the fabulous, friendly, go-out-of-their-way service I have experienced here before. Given the chance, I'll probably stay here again, but not as enthusiastically as in the past.

<Author>Marilynn1313
<Content>Amazing Caribe!!!! We have just returned from a wonderful vacation at the Caribe Hilton Resort and cannot say enough about their staff and the treatment we received! I travelled with my 19 year old daughter and my seven year old and I have to say, the staff was very nice and they certainly went out of their way to accomodate children of all ages, myself included, LOL!!. One instance in particular. We were fish feeding by the small pier next to the beach area when my son's favorite hat in the whole world flew away and landed in the water between the rocks. He was devastated!! This hat has alot of sentimental value to my son, so I took a chance and asked two employees if there was anything they can do. Without question or hestitation these nice gentlemen sprung into action and before I knew it they climbed onto the rocks (which is prohibited to vacationers) and used a tool that extended very far out and managed to capture my son's hat. I was cheering and people around me kept asking what's going on?, when I told them, they just shrugged their shoulders. My son was totally elated and thanked each and every one of them with a big hug. This was definitely a Catch Me At My Best Caribe Moment. The room was absolutely beautiful with an ocean view and immaculate. The food in Palmeras Restaurant was great and even though we weren't VIP's, we were treated like one...See you next summer Caribe!!!!  
<Date>Jul 27, 2007

<Author>aidawedo
<Content>not bad at all After seeing all of the mixed reviews I was nervous about staying at the Hilton. It was good, clean, a decent place. I decided to try it for a 22 hour layover. One thing that you may like about this hotel is that the beach is private. Also there is NOTHING around the hotel area if you walk about a mile there is a park but it is pretty isolated, there are no restaurants or stores outside of the Hilton except for a crappy little Subway so you better have a car or be prepared to spend on a taxi. Yes it was expensive with everything one night is $363 for a single occupant. Good things: starbucks in lobby, private beach, nice layout. I did not understand the review that said that the beach was too far it was right there. Downside: the beach is not open so you can't go for long walks. I would recommend this place for people who want privacy and people who have kids! they have loads of stuff for kids to do on the premises and if I came with my family I would consider that. For my next layover I stayed at the intercontinental and you can read my review of that.  
<Date>Jul 25, 2007

<Author>claudis927
<Content>Our Honeymoon We got a great deal for our honeymoon at the Caribe Hilton!!! We had booked plane tickets but didnt have a hotel until a week before our trip. Caribe Hilton was the best deal, not too much money. The room did not have the greatest view, but I believe is because we pay the lowest price. We did not care anyway!! We only went there to sleep. the hotel grounds were great. The pool, the bar, the beach, the view.....was like paradise!!!!. The food was excellent, I never had a bad meal. ALthought the food was expensive ($75 dollars and up for two) we did not care, we were in our honeymoon and we had the best time. Old San Juan is just minutes away!! they had great Shops and restaurants. El morro is also minutes away. We cant imagine getting a better deal!!!! I cant wait to book my other trip and go back to the Caribe Hilton again.

<Author>DawgAlberta
<Content>Over Priced We stayed at both the Intercontinental and the Caribe Hilton in San Juan. We found the Intercontinental vastly superior to the Hilton.The Hilton is way overpriced. The food and drink prices are too high for the quality. Our room while spacious, was noisy (inside) from the elevators, and very noisy on the balcony from the roof top air conditioning units. One morning there was no hot water. To top it off, on the last morning we had a nice cockroach beside our bed.All of the employees were exceptionally nice. If you are looking at on or the other definitely stay at the Intercontinental

<Author>DC_dinks
<Content>Caribe Hilton and its Pia Coladas We stayed at the Caribe Hilton for four nights in June 2005. We were apprehensive at first because of the many bad reviews but when we arrived, the staff checked us in right away and when we asked for an upgrade, they gave it to us. We stayed in a renovated room in the new tower and it was great, with a beautiful ocean view. The beach was clean, and you could order anything from the hotel and they serve it to you right there. There was a slide in the water which was a lot of fun. The concierge was really helpful when it came to recommending restaurants in Old San Juan. Oh, and it was quite easy to get around using the cabs. Some of the reviewers mentioned that the cab rides were expensive, but for us (we live in DC), it was really inexpensive (around $6 to get into town). Overall, a great experience at a lovely hotel.  
<Date>Jul 18, 2007

<Author>TJinSTL
<Content>Could Be Just What You Want I just took my team on a 4-day trip to Caribe Hilton. If given the chance to do it over, I would certainly return. My wife and I (particularly my wife) are very discriminating travelers. Were we to go to Puerto Rico alone, we'd be unlikely to return. However, the Caribe Hilton was certainly fine enough to satisfy us (even her), and for a work-outing, it was a perfect fit.The outside areas of the hotel are beautifully done. The water is great, the resort property is vast and diverse, and in general, it was well-kept. The public areas of the hotel were spacious, clean and inviting. As for the rooms, this is not a new hotel. It has gone through a major renovation and we were not displeased - but you can only cover up so much in a 50-year hotel. Be sure you stay in one of the newer sections of the property! Here are some I shared with our travel agent who had directed us to this property:1. For what it is, the resort is great. Compared to other convention resorts, it scores well. As a high-end luxury retreat, it would not fare as well. The property is definately feeling its age - even in the tower where we stayed, they can only paint over, plaster over and carpet over so much. The common areas were good, and the pool/beach areas were laid out very nicely. But, it's not a new hotel.2. I found the location to be excellent. It's 10 minutes from the airport, within walking distance of casinos and restaurants, and its location on the water was great. The property is basically encased by two old forts, surrounded by a low stone wall, and in beautiful water. The outdoor area offers a great combination of pool (with waterfalls), beach, shaded hammocks, and grassy areas lined with palms.3. The spa was top notch. This includes the fitness center. High marks all around.4. We ate at two of the on-property restaurants. I would suggest doing no more than eating lunch at the property. The restaurants weren't bad, they just were very over-priced for what ended up being pretty pedestrian food and service.5. We went to three restaurants for dinner in Old San Juan. One was a local dive in a neighborhood we probably shouldn't have ventured to ... but it was great. The other two we would highly recommend: The Parrott Club and Aqua Viva. Great Food, Great Service and Great Atmosphere at both.  
<Date>Jul 9, 2007

<Author>headstraight
<Content>Super Hilton My family and I just came back from San Juan P.R. and we spent 7 days at the Hilton caribe and I must say that we enjoyed every moment of our stay. The staff was courteous and accomodatin. The pools were clean and the private beach was beutiful and safe for a five year old. I stayed in the Tower building and those rooms were great with a beutiful view of the beach and front garden. The room was clean and the bathromm was expansive and did not have any mildew or other growths on the fixtures or walls. The only drawback to the hotel was that the hotel is somewhat isolated from other places. So you are pretty much trapped in the facility, unless you want to spend cab money to get to the hotel and restaurant strip in Condado (half a mile or so away). If not, bring your wallet the food and drink prices are expensive (about $100.00 a day for a family of three) and they do not offer a package with meals. If you are adventerous, rent a car from Dollar across the street and explore the other parts of the island, it comes out somewhat less then the activity packages they offer. one other thing DO NOT DRIVE INTO OLD SAN JUAN take a taxi, it is better for your health and sanity.  
<Date>Jul 8, 2007

<Author>love2traveltogether
<Content>Beautiful for a price.... My husband and I just returned from a 3 night stay at the Caribe Hilton Hotel in beautiful San Juan, Puerto Rico. I have been traveling to Puerto Rico all of my life and used to stay in the Caribe Hilton in the 1970's-1980's. The hotel recently underwent rennovations in the lobby. The rennovations are nice but to me I feel that the hotel has lost a lot of it's Puerto Rican charm. It seems to have become a mega resort. What I mean by that, is that it is not anymore a tranquil hotel as I remembered from my youth but is now a bustling resort with too many people and extremely high prices. We stayed in a garden room on the 10th floor. We had a beautiful view of the gardens below, the beautiful sea surrounding us and the historic fort. The rooms are pretty well maintained although I do think they can use some rennovations. The first and last nights that we stayed at the hotel were very nice and quiet. However the 2nd night of our stay was horrible. I cannot say it is the fault of the hotel but the people staying around us. They were slamming the doors all night long which of course made it very difficult to sleep. On our first day there we arrived around lunch time and had lunch in the grille. The food was very good and the lunch menu was pretty reasonable. We also decided to have dinner there. They offer different buffets every night of the week and although the food looked good we decided to order off of the menu. The dinner was o.k. and again the prices were o.k. On our second day we decided to have breakfast also in the grille. Well, this is where they really get you. When we first sat down they did not give us a menu. There was however a menu on the table. The menu only showed 2 or 3 options and then the $20.50 buffet. Well we are not huge eaters and so did not want to spend the $20.50 for the small amount of food we would be eating. We were about to leave when my husband asked if that was all they served. At that point, the waiter said, oh, no, we have another menu. I am assuming from what happened to us, that they try to get everyone to order the buffet so they do not give the full menu unless you ask for it. Well, needless to say, we ordered from the regular menu and to be perfectly honest, we ended up spending the same amount that we would have spent had we ordered the buffet. For an order of French Toast, eggs, orange juice and a cup of coffee it ended up costing us over $40.00. We have stayed in many resorts of this kind and even larger ones and have never, ever paid anything like that for breakfast. With that being said, I feel like they definitely take advantagebecause there are not a lot of places to go that are near the hotel. Fortunately, there is a Starbucks in the lobby and although you cannot get a hot breakfast from them at least you can get something to hold you over for breakfast and not spend a ton of money. We opted to eat breakfast at Starbucks for the remainder of our stay and it actually was quite good.  If you are looking for Puerto Rican cuisine in the Condado area, we ate at 2 pretty good restaurants for dinner. The first was Ajili Mojili. It is pretty moderately priced and the atmosphere and most important the food was very good. The other place I would recommend would be Ropa Vieja. If you only have one night to eat in the Condado area then this is the place I would say to visit. The atmosphere is really nice and the food is wonderful. Check out the spa at the Normandie Hotel, right next to the Caribe Hilton. Although it is a very small spa, the service is excellent and the prices are very reasonable.All in all, the Caribe Hilton is a beautiful resort, but due to the high prices, crowds and location, in the future I will probably opt for a different hotel for my stay in the San Juan area.  
<Date>Jul 5, 2007

<Author>Kione
<Content>Typical Resort To my knowledge, this is one of the only full resort hotels actually located in old San Juan, although you will still need to take a $10 taxi to get to El Moro or SoFo or anywhere else (cab service is expensive in PR). On the other hand, you could just spend the entire day relaxing at the Hilton's massive private beach, spa and pool area - which is what we did while we were there.The rooms are clean and the view we had was excellent. All of our interactions with the staff were very pleasant. If you upgrade to their executive service you get access to a special room where they serve continental breakfast, happy hour appetizers and late night dessert. There are shops, restaurants and even a Starbucks at the hotel but everything is predictably bland and overpriced.This is a perfectly nice place to lie in the sand all day with a book and a cocktail, but there is nothing remarkable about the hotel.  
<Date>Jul 5, 2007

<Author>UDSL05
<Content>Nice resort with prime location My wife and I stayed at this hotel for a few nights at the end of June. It has wonderful beaches, pools, and restaurants. The best part was its location. The hotel is far enough away from Old San Juan that it has its own beach and privacy, but yet just a short cab ride away. The other major resorts are out by the airport. There is so much happening in Old San Juan it was nice to be so close. The staff is very friendly and helpful. There is an excursions desk across from the concierge, we used both and were impressed with the recommendations and excursions. We highly recommend the illumincecnet bay, that alone is worth a trip to Puerto Rico. It should be noted, that the rooms do not have the fit and finish of the hotels of this caliber in major North American or even European cities. These things were all minor, but I thought I would mention them because if you are expecting comparable four or five star accommodations you might be disappointed. If you are looking to have fun, relax, and enjoy the island then you will enjoy this hotel.  
<Date>Jun 30, 2007

<Author>travellorzl
<Content>I was scared to death, but... I was scared to death upon reading some reviews and called to cancel but was asked not to. Upon our arrival, it was as if they had read every negative review and sought to correct things. We lucked out with no wait to check-in, our room was ready despite a brief scare and a bell person was at our taxi the second we arrived. Our room was 1564 and the view was simply unbeatable (no exaggeration). The rooms in the tower are not spacious, they are actually smallish but not the filth factory I envisioned though the maids had not looked in the tv cabinet that had something most vile in it. It still smelled after having been removed. While the shower was large I could not get the water to get hot-ever. There was intrigue about the towels; though I asked for extra towels 3 additional sets to accompany the 1 existing set-each day, the maid would take the additional sets and only ever leave 1 set. The restaurants were pricey but really no different that any restaurant in a hotel. We did make use of the minimart/mompop across the street. We ate in the hotel palmeras restaurant and got the buffet (lamb/steak) $39.00 and found the food delicious and the service exceptional and gave the waiter a fantastic tip. The pina colada we tried (at the pool) was just horrible, the ameretto sours inside the bar area made my chest hurt (they had real booze-I allowed my chest to keep hurting). I was still alittle haunted by the bad reviews so we did alittle checking, we walked down the halls of the main building and did smell something moldy though we could not see inside the rooms-so don discount those reviews-those candid reviews saved us a horror show described by so many. A lot was made about the executive lounge-it has light snacks and a cash bar-it is not worth paying anything extra for.Watch out for the birds-they seem friendly enough but we witnessed alittle aviary violence-the white cockatoo bit a man that had monopolized it for at least 30 minutes. You can have a good time at this hotel-if you use it for sleeping and a meal or two and the pool-it is not the main attraction-Puerto Rico is so see it.  
<Date>Jun 29, 2007

<Author>SCChuck
<Content>Great but pricey The Caribe Hilton is a great hotel - close to Old San Juan, ports and airport without being right on top of any of them. Our reservations were made at a good rate but that may be, at least in part, because of the whole passport busines. The rooms were very nice and service was very good. The best part about this hotel is the pool and beach. The pool is very nice but sometimes crowded and the beach is very nice and relatively quiet. Hammocks among the palm trees was the highlight. We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights before taking a cruise and got just what we bargained for, a chance to unwind.Now, the bad news. The cost of a single mixed drink, with a modest tip, will set you back $11. And, while they have 4 restaurants on the premises, they all charge Hilton prices. We saved some cash by eating several meals at the Subway nearby and taking advantage of the small market, where you can buy a liter of PR's finest for less than the cost of one mixed drink by the pool. There are no other restaurants nearby. However, for the price of a roundtrip cab ride (about $25 - both directions) you can have a nice meal in Old San Juan and still save money.We learned from the concierge that massive renovations are due later this year - probably October to November and by the size of the renovations, I would expect a stay at the Caribe to be less enjoyable than it would be today. I would definitely call and ask about the status of renovations before making a reservation.  
<Date>Jun 28, 2007

<Author>tfly5331
<Content>Old and Tired Hotel My wife and I stayed at this hotel May 18-23, 2007. We are Hilton Diamond Club members so we were supposed to get the best room they had available. Well, that didn't happen. Our room was on the 16th floor, just above the major construction site of the new Hilton casino. We did have a view of the ocean/bay but we had to go out on the patio to see it.  The rooms were ok and the beds were comfortable. The maid service was good - nothing to complain about but nothing to rave about either.  The prices of food and drinks at the hotel are outrageous! We went across the street to a convenience store and bought our drinks and snacks. We ate breakfast in the hotel (it was free) but all other meals were taken in Old San Juan. Puerto Rican food is just terrific. You can only experience the REAL Pureto Rican culture and food if you eat in an authentic Puerto Rican restaurant. The Caribe Hilton restaurants have a lot to offer for those of you who want to throw your money away. However, I highly recommend you venture out to other restaurants for your meals. Finally, I'll say that the grounds/landscape of the Hilton hotel arealso old and tired. The pools are nice but had STUFF floating in the main pool every night (we have no idea what it was but we have suspicions!) and the beach on the ocean is protected by a sea wall. We couldn't take the constantly screaming kids at the beach or the pool area so our trips to the beach and pool were few and far between - what a waste.  All in all, we did enjoy the city of Old San Juan and a big plus is that the beds in the Caribe Hilton were comfortable. Thats about it.....I don't like to be negative.  
<Date>Jun 27, 2007

<Author>Chris&Erik
<Content>Service oriented hotel My husband and I stayed at the Hilton 6/8 through 6/17. We found the staff to be very accommodating and friendly. It is unfortunate that there is some major construction going on but if you are at the front of the hotel, you do not hear it. Avoid the villas until the construction is complete! We had a beautiful view from our 13th floor tower room and found the room clean and mold free. It is nice that they provide mini fridges instead of mini bars. You can buy juices etc at the store across from the hotel. The grounds are beautiful, pool is great, and beach area is ok. There is an area of shaded hammocks that are very inviting. While you are wandering the grounds grab a handful of bread from the towel stand and head out the pier to feed the fish.The restaurants in the hotel are pretty good. Our least favorite was the Italian, too much salt used. Our favorite was the Lemon Grass. Order the filet with stilton sauce. YUM! Do not forget to say hi to Victor and Manuel, the day bartenders in the hotel lobby bar. They take VERY good care of you.Overall, we had a wonderful vacation and will go back next time we go to PR.

<Author>Radiovet
<Content>Disappointment This was once a great hotel but with time and the add ons it has suffered. The drink machine offered soft drinks at $250. each but was empty. After taking our three ones it coughed back a one and two dollars in dimes. At that price you'd think they'd keep it full.Food is extremely expensive. Breakfast for one will hit you for $30. and is average at best. Forget room service. The taxes and fees drive up the cost of a less than spectacular meal beyond where one likes to go.A $214. room rate gets more than $50. a night tacked on in taxes and resort fees. Couple all of this with a staff that has few gems in it and it is best to find another place to stay. We found the people to be condescending, partial to other Spanish speaking folks and in some instances simply rude. I had not been back to Caribe Hilton for 20 years but remembered it fondly. That memory has been updated. Sadly the hotel hasn't.

<Author>JoAnnPittsburghPA
<Content>Not Happy with the Caribe Hilton or San Juan We just returned from San Juan, stayed at the Caribe Hilton, June 2nd thru June 9th. Had to change rooms 4 times requested the Hilton Towers and they put us in the main building it was very old and and dirty tub was moldy and there were holes in the walls and ceiling. Asked to be moved 2nd day, we were moved to the towers 12th floor it was nice much better room and an excellent view. Got up next morning to find check out papers from the room when I called front desk they said that the room was booked and we would have to move. We were moved to the 5th floor construction all day and no view, went down to see manager and he could not understand why the moved us but said he would put us in nice room. Finally in nice room but each time we were given a room we had to wait till 6pm to get in the room. My husband said good thing we had suitcases with wheels cause he said they got warn out from moving. The showers were nice BUT in every room there was mold on the floor they could use some clorox to clean them. I didnot find the people in San Juan to be friendly, everyone spoke Spanish, it is very expensive. All the fees they add to your room is crazy, plus to get a cab anywhere it was $15 each way and they tell you its not safe to walk. I did not find the beach to be very nice, I did think the pool was nice. If you eat breakfast in the restaurant it is over priced and the service is very bad. I feel this Hotel is more for business travelers and they are more receptive to people coming for conferences. I guess all in all I will not go back to the Caribe Hilton. We actually tried to book a cruise out of San Juan the first Sunday we were there but the change in the airline ticket would have cost us another $1,000 so we decided to stay and make the best of it. There is no place like the Radisson in Aruba, way way better....
