<Author>THPPFT
<Content>Nothing special Stayed 3 days mid-May for a biz conference. Arrived promptly at check in time on a Thursday to be told my long-reserved room was booked, with the inference I should have arrived earlier (!) This after being ignored in the Hilton Honors special check in line which the desk clerks studiously ignored. Stuck in a garden room with no sealed windows the first night, moved myself for the next night (after being told to leave my bags packed for the day, that they would move them) and got a room in the Honors tower just above a long expanse of roof and exhaust vents, the ocean in the distance. One has the impression that those paying the rack rate get the nice rooms, everyone else is everyone else. Room was fairly large and nicely furnished, ditto the bathroom, pool is quite small given the # of rooms here, nearby beach is a better bet. Local street access is tough to follow, best to look in the sky for the Hilton mural on the tower if you're driving and just aim for it. All in all just average, the 10% resort fee was overreaching, the checkin experience was the worst part of the stay and I'll stay elsewhere next time.  
<Date>Jun 5, 2007

<Author>urbanistaNYC
<Content>Great hotel, best vacation ever We just came back from a week-long vacation in San Juan, PR. I read reviews of multiple hotels before made reservations and decided to stay at Caribe Hilton. Great choice!I was a little concerned about reviews that mentioned molding rooms that smelled awful. As soon as I booked my trip I called the hotel directly and asked for a recently renovated room. My request was honored. We were placed in HH Towers. The room was great - we asked for 2 double beds - they were so comfortable. The room was rather spacious and the bathroom was great too - with nice shower. I read in one of the reviews that if you stay in the Towers you get access to free continental breakfast. Right on! We got free breakfast every morning - just swipe your access key and it works. Another tip -- there are free appetizers and rather cheap alcohol between 5 and 7.30pm every day served in the same lounge where you eat breakfast. Everybody complains about how expensive everything at the resort is, but if you go to the executive lounge you get $3 glass of wine and $4 hard liquor.... you can beat that, can you? Plus you get free appetizers.About food - I live in NYC so to me it didn seem overpriced. There is Subway next to the hotel but I would rather personally get a nice sandwich and salad at the Grill at the Hotel for $7 than a nasty sandwich at Subway for $5. You decide. Food is delicious at all the restaurants located in this hotel.The hotel itself is beautiful. I don know what others complain about - lobby is spectacular, the beach area is secluded and just perfect. Pool area is large too. No problem getting towels or umbrella.Staff is very friendly and ready to help. Example: I was ordering lunch while lounging by the pool. The waiter came over to take my order. She asked if I wanted a drink - I said no and she saw that I had a bottle of water standing on my table. In few minutes she came back with my sandwich and glass full of ice- I didn even ask for it! That what I call great service- when you don even have to ask for it. Condado area is located across a bridge and is about 15-20 min walk away. There are many restaurants there. I was not impressed by any of them. But again, I am very picky having lived in NYC. There is a small convenience store next to the hotel. If you are out of sunscreen, don buy it at the store located on hotel's premises (outrageous prices) - walk a few steps over to the convenience store and pay just $7.As far as activities are concerned, we went on sailing and snorkeling tour which was great! They take you to 2 different islands and there is so much fish there, it breathtaking. I booked the trip at the activities desk at the hotel. It was $89/person including tax and it included free bus ride to Fajardo area as well.We also went to Old San Juan - not on tour, just took a cab - it was $12 on the way there and $10 back. We went to El Morro - admission is $3/person and it was really cool. The food was way better in Old San Juan than in Condado. Try Berlin Cafe. It was great.We didnt rent a car - we figured we would not need it. There are cabs everywhere and there is so much to do at the hotel plus the different tours available i thought it was unnecessary to have a car.  
<Date>May 31, 2007

<Author>Jolenie
<Content>Good enough I had some trepidations about staying at this hotel after reading some of the other reviews. After a pleasant four day stay at this hotel, I have to conclude that those who hated the place either had unrealistic expectations, or they were given a completely unrenovated room.  The reviews indicate that the Garden rooms were the worst, so we knew that we wouldn't agree to stay in that wing. We did request the Hilton Honors tower, and were somewhat surprised and disappointed when we were told that they didn't have a room available in the tower. However, we were given a room on one of the higher floors in the main building, which they considered to be an executive room. Perks included use of the Executive room which provided a free Continental breakfast, coctail hour (mainly cheese and fruit), dessert in the evening, and free access to the internet. Given the expensive restaurants in the hotel, the breakfast saved us a decent amount of money, and consisted of the usual Continental fare. The food was constantly being replenished by the staff. The room was on the smaller side, but not tiny. It had relatively new carpeting and a decent bathroom. It was well maintained and very clean. The duvet cover was pilling which was annoying because the white threads stuck to our pj's, but otherwise, the bed was comfortable.The lobby was attractive and open. The beach was great for swimming and kayaking. I loved it because the water was calm and clear. For those who like to surf, find another hotel. Palm trees provided shade if you didn't want to get an umbrella. Chairs were plentiful on the beach and by the pool. The restaurants were generally overpriced and the food just OK, except for the Lemongrass which was fabulous. It was romantic and the food was wonderful. All in all, if you view the Caribe Hilton as a 3.5 star hotel and not a 4 star hotel, you shouldn't be disappointed. We liked the fact that it was not on a crowded strip, like most of the other hotels in the Condado area and in Isla Verde.  
<Date>May 29, 2007

<Author>Mike_Weatherford
<Content>Okay room, great beach We chose the Caribe Hilton as the hotel to spend the night at prior to the cruise. I tried on several occasions to get one of the great rates that others had reported by using Priceline.com, but was never able to get my bid accepted. Finally, about a month or so out, I booked an ocean view room at full price. We arrived at 3:00 pm, only to find out our room wasn ready yet ?which was to be somewhat expected, as our reservations stated the room would be ready by 4:00. We were told we could use the changing facilities and the pool area while we were waiting if we wanted. Our room was made available to us promptly at 4:00 pm. We were in the lder?section of the hotel, and the hallway smelled slightly musty. The room felt somewhat dated, and probably not what I would normally expect for a high end hotel (and a high price tag). It was however in good repair, and more than adequate for our one night stay. I have read that if you complain, you may get upgraded to one of the newer rooms, but again, we were only here for one night, and the room was more than adequate. The grounds however were stunning! The beach and pool areas were immaculate. We spent the early evening, and the next morning snorkeling in the beach swimming area, and were surprised by the number of fish we saw. One word of caution: If you plan to eat at the hotel, plan on dropping some serious coin, even for a hamburger ($16.50 as I recall). Never fear though, there is a Subway just around the corner, and a Starbucks in the hotel for some reasonable breakfast snacks. Check out time was noon, so around eleven we checked out, and stored our bags in the lobby area so that we could do a little sight seeing down town before boarding the cruise ship. If you are looking for some beach time, this may be a good choice for you. If you are just looking for a place to lay your head, find something cheaper - unless of coarse you are willing to pony up for one of the executive rooms!  
<Date>May 14, 2007

<Author>amidelaplage
<Content>Be advised about this Hilton We stayed at this Hilton due to it's great location, attractive grounds and Hilton's reputation for quality. Though recently remodeled, it was evident that the hotel rooms were tired older rooms with simply some fancy new furnishigs. They failed to warn us that the ocean views were obstructed by construction, unless you stay in the higher floors. I must admit though, the bed was comforatable and the pillows were wonderful. We spent some time laying in the sun and watching families swim in the hotel's cove, only to learn from the local news later that evening that there was a city-wide alert warning people not to swim in the waters near the hotel that day due to a health hazard having to do with raw sewage being dumped into the ocean water nearby. We were surprised that the hotel chose not to limit access to the cove by its guest. Finally, when we were checking out of the hotel, we noticed a charge was posted on our bill titled Voluntary Contribution to the Children of Puerto Rico fund or similar. There was nothing voluntary about it. Apparently they conveniently slip this charge into the room bills, and unless you happen to notice and dispute it, you pay it. I told some Puerto Rican friends about this and they found it humorous that the hotel would attempt such a thing, assuring me that the funds did not get used for that purpose. So, for the next time I stay at the Caribe Hilton, I would like to thank them in advance for the voluntary contribution of a comfy fluffy Hilton pillow my luggage, as my wife so happens to be a former Child of Puerto Rico. Seriously, if you stay at the Caribe Hilton in San Juan, ask questions and don't take anything for granted.  
<Date>May 13, 2007

<Author>movedsouth
<Content>Enjoyed our stay! We spent 8 days in early April at the Caribe Hilton. We had a room in the Hilton Honors tower (15th floor) with ocean view. We were traveling on Hilton points and my husbnad was a diamond member. First, we really enjoyed our very relaxing stay. Our room was small for four people. There was not a lot of room to put away all the clothes. So, we had one living out of a suitcase. The room itself was in decent shape. I think it could use new carpeting. The bathroom was updated recently. We had a great view of the ocean and the beds were very comfortable. Make sure you get a topsheet on your bed. We did not and asked for one. We ate breakfast downstairs at the Hilton Honors free breakfast. It was perfect for our family as it had bagels, cereal and fruit and sweets.There is soda and water available all day at the Honors room and also had free appetizers at night. Lunches we had mostly by the pool/beach area. We found the food to be fresh and good. Dinners on property we had were, Madrid-This was just okay. I would not return although the waiters were very nice, the food was pricey and very mediocre. Il Giardano-The italian restaurant was our favorite. I would gladly go back. I had the veal parmigiana and it was excellent. We also ate twice in the buffet restaurant for dinner called Palmeras. The roasted meats night was a good variety and we enjoyed it and found the price reasonable. The lobster night was expensive and disappointing. I would not go back for that.The grounds are large and have everything for a relaxing vacation. We were truly spent much of our town at the resort. The beach is small, but the ocean was calm enough for the kids to swim and enjoy. There was very good snorkeling around the rock areas and my husband learned to scuba dive next door and swam just past the rocks with the scuba group. He said this was the best experience and highly recommends it. We would definitely go back to the Caribe Hilton. I think some rooms are older and more worn than others. I also think a smile and a gracias goes a long way. Be polite and people were very friendly. Enjoy!  
<Date>May 9, 2007

<Author>queenbuc
<Content>Not worth the money!!! Just came back from an all girls trip to Puerto Rico. We originally booked the Caribe Hilton with the expectations of a nice hotel. The lobby was beautiful but after seeing the room we quickly exited stageleft. Definitely not worth the money!! We got the unrenovated side. There are a lot of options in Puerto Rico and if you are going to pay, you might as well get a nice option. So we headed over to the Marriott. It was beautiful. The lobby was nice. The bell men were cute and the rooms were clean and nicely decorated. Our first room had some leakage problems and we were promptly relocated (with help) and given a $100 credit. After realizing all the taxi rides were going to cost a small fortune, we chose the bus. Only $.75 each way! The bus goes everywhere from Old San Juan to Isle Verde and even the airport. Old San Juan is nice and perfect for tourists. We found a little shack by the port that served the best Marlin pastelillos, the manager, Andres is really nice. We also caught the ferry over to the Bacardi plant for free drinks!!! The souvenir shops definitely weren as cheap as the Bahamas. The clubs were okay. Too many young people though. Senior Frogs has a great atmosphere but leaves something to be desired in the food department. We decided we wanted to get away from the tourist spots and wanted to rent a car. The Hertz desk at the hotel wanted $40 a day!!! So I went down to the business center which is open 24 hours a day and booked a small compact car using Hotwire for $12.95 a day. The total for the day was less than $20. The only bad thing is the $14 parkingfee at the hotel is ridiculous!!! We rode the bus to the airport, picked up the car, and hit the highway. There are small tolls as you drive up the highway, the most expensive one was $1.50. We drove up to the El Yunque rainforest, which was only a 45 minute drive. The tours from area hotels range from $40-$50. So we were expecting an entrance fee of some sort. Well to our surprise it was completely FREE. We walked thetrail to the La Mina waterfall. We didn go to the peak this time, we heard it was beautiful. Either way, you can beat this FREE excursion.All in all we had a great trip to Puerto Rico. I would stay at the Marriott again, however, I would rather rent a condo off the beach.  
<Date>May 8, 2007

<Author>towing3
<Content>Great Stay My wife and I went down for our 25th and had a great stay. Had a room in the main Bldg. in the executive floor. Had a view of the lagoon and ocean, very nice view. Very quite and laid back. Room was very nice and cleaned everyday. The view from the other side is of the ocean and the city. Were givin the chance to have either view. The exective lounge was a great extra to have. Very nice Cont. breakfast in the morning for free and were able to get water , soda for the beach for the afternoon. Save alot of money that way. Pool and the lagoon were real nice and clean. Not very many people were there so we could sit almost any where we wanted to. Service at the swim up bar was ok. Morton,s steak house was GREAT. Went into town for another dinner, the cab into old san jaun was 10.00 plus 2.00 tip. Also went to the El San Juan hotel and casino for a 20.00 cab. Hilton was a great place to really relax and just chill out and enjoy the good weather. PS. If you get a room in the new towers bldg. it is a pretty long walk to the pool and lagoon. The main Bldg. is right next to everything. The Garden view section has its own pool but very small and people tell me the rooms are very old too. If you want to just get away and chill out , the hilton is the place to do that.

<Author>SuzyNy
<Content>Disappointed Hello-We just got back from a week at the Caribe Hilton. My husband  I were there from April 25 to May 2nd. This is a big hotel with over 800 rooms. Check in time is 4pm  check out is noon. There is the main building (original building)  the tower section. Try to stay in the tower section, as these rooms were supposedly newly renovated. We stayed on the 9th floor of the main building. We were supposed to have an ocean view. The rooms are not directly facing the water, so we had a side view. Unfortunately also overlooking the top of the building  had to deal with noise from some sort of motor. We were offered to make a move, but had to wait a few days-so we stayed where we were-but did not relax sitting on the patio (which was small anyway). The room could have used some pdating? It does have a coffeemaker, un-stocked refrigerator, a safe, ironing board, iron  blow dryer. You can order room service, keep in mind they charge you an extra 15% gratuity, plus $3.00 delivery charge~ a  grapefruit cost $5.50, a pint of Haagen Daaz was $14. There is also pay per view to order on the tv in the room, but they charge about $13-$15 to watch a movie. So stick with the tv choices. The plus, if you had a laptop they did have in room a high speed internet connection. The beach is very small  does look like it was a man-made beach. Yes it is private  they made a wall of rocks to keep the water calm. Not a lot of space on the beach, so there is a cement decking where a lot of people chose to relax. You can rent an umbrella, floats, snorkeling mask($10 hour) etc. There is also a shaded area with a few hammocks. There is a multi level pool  two Jacuzzis on one side of the hotel, the other side had a smaller pool  jacuzzi. There is a dock you can walk out  look at the fish-you can feed them left over bread (ask at the towel hut). There is a pretty tropical garden with swans  other birds  koi swimming on the side of the hotel. After being used to going to ll-Inclusive?resorts, this was a BIG shock to us on the prices of food  drinks. They did have a few restaurants to choose from-orton Steakhouse? adrid-San Juan?Spanish), otisserie Il Giardino?Northern Italian),emongrass?Pan Asian Latino), almeras?offers buffet dining options also, breakfast was $20.50 per person, las Health Bar? tlantico?snack bar dining outside)  a tarbucks? They also had the asis Bar?inside with nightly entertainment  a small swim up bar in the pool ?not that big of an area-more of a walk up bar in the water with stools. The food we ate there was good?but very expensive!!! You can walk to a ubway?about 5 minute walk- but they are doing some work on that street  there is a horrible odor-so that was not an option for us. You should try to get the xecutive?plan-as they offer you a continental breakfast in the morning, cookies  fruit in the afternoon, hor doeuvres in the evening  desserts later. You also get free coffee, tea, soda, juice  water there. Also there is a computer to check your emails. There is a nice BIG health club with 30 cardiovascular  circuit training machines-treadmills,steppers,ellipticals,bicycles,rowing machine,versa climber,free weights  lex Fitness Circuit Training System? They do offer babysitting  there is a kids club, game room, playground(which we did not have use for). They had a daily schedule of activities, but unfortunately it rained for most of our trip, so we did not partake. There is a spa as well, offering massages,facials,body  water therapies. They have a car rental place  some stores(drugstore type store, gift shop, upscale boutiques). They have a travel desk-which again seemed pricey. We did the Camuey Caves  observatory-about $83 a person. The caves were okay, the observatory was a waste-they don explain about anything. My husband wanted to go fishing ?he had a lot of problems arranging that. That is not a popular place to go out fishing. He do go out for a half a day  they did not catch anything, plus it was about $200 for himself to share a boat. It gets expensive traveling ?the taxis charge a few dollars extra from the hotel to go someplace. Most taxi rides are about $15 plus tip. Try to take the bus to Old San Juan, for 50 cents. Really is not much in walking distance  because of all the construction, we chose not to walk. This was not an issue though, as we were concerned. Maybe because of all the rain we had, they were not working. If money is not an issue  a small beach is alright ?then I guess if you stay in the tower section this would be alright-seems more of a place to go for business meetings not a real relaxing, beautiful vacation. Everything there is very expensive  overall did not find most of the people friendly. As for us, we would not go back again.  
<Date>May 6, 2007

<Author>MidgeInMichigan
<Content>Lovely stay in Puerto Rico We loved our week long stay at the Caribe Hilton in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The landscaping was incredibly beautiful with just about every type of palm tree swaying in the constant breeze from the ocean. The multiple pools including one with an infinity edge were inviting and refreshing. The service we received was excellent! The reservationists, bell captains, waiters, security personnel, housekeeping and maintenance were friendly and very helpful. The Olas Spa is a must for anyone who needs a little pampering. They also had a nice variety of restaurants and a couple of bars right on site. Our only criticism was the extremely high prices for food and drink at the hotel. Drinks including Beer started at around $8 each and most ala carte entrees including pasta dishes started at $25 and up. Of course, you could always go into town to eat but prices were a bit high there as well. All in all, we would definately recommend the Hilton Caribe to those looking to stay in Puerto Rico!  
<Date>May 6, 2007

<Author>KO75
<Content>No thank you, Caribe Hilton I was very disappointed. I did a lot of research on properties in San Juan so that my family and I would have a great vacation. (husband, myself, and two kids 2  7). Despite the reviews I had read for months (thinking the people were overcritical) I booked it anyway. I had a rate of 230 per night but felt that with all the promises it was worth it. The lobby is beautiful and the Starbucks is good...the private beach was fine...We arrived on the last flight into San Juan and arrived to the hotel about 11pm...we were not taken to the room until about midnight. It was an ordeal getting checked in and I was a HIlton Honors member. I had requested an upper level floor...I was given the Garden Terrace (if you get this...change it immediately). We had to take an elevator down to our room. People joked and asked if we were sleeping in the basement. The Garden Terrace is a decent hotel room with a dirty patio...with dirty cheap patio furniture...overlooking the facilities area with the exception of the plants/foliage that is place in front of the patio. There are walkways on the other side of your hedge. I did not feel it was worth staying at the hotel in that room for 230 a night (along with the 5 dollar per person...including children...surcharge per day...that's an extra hundred dollars on the bill). I spent two hours on the internet (wifi was an extra 15 dollars a day) looking for something else...not an easy feat during spring break...but we found something great and I am pleased that I was given the room otherwise I probably wouldn't have been motivated to move. If you want more choices for restaurants and shops...Isla Verde is better located.  
<Date>Apr 27, 2007

<Author>DebFMichigan
<Content>Beautiful grounds We were booked in a double double Villa (supposedly an upgraded room) which we found very cramped. They add a small bar type sink, a second fridge and a microwave to the Villa but the bathroom and room itself is much smaller than the Tower double double rooms. We switched to the Tower because the room was small and the view was of a construction site next door. Tower room more spacious with a beautiful view, fridge, large closet and huge bathroom with walk in shower. I would have preferred two Queen beds instead of the two Double beds which were very small. The grounds are the best part of the hotel. They have a beautiful pool area, shaded area with palm trees and hammocks and their own lagoon with beach. A lot of the hotels say ocean front but have no beach access. We never had a problem finding a lounge chair no matter what time we got downstairs. The staff will even bring you an umbrella and put it in the ground for you (free of charge). The staff is friendly and helpful. The food is very expensive. We spent $100 for four of us for a breakfast buffett. After that we had the free Hilton Honors breakfast and ate elsewhere for all meals. The hotel is a short cab ride to the airport as well as Old San Juan. I'd stay there again, mostly because of the grounds and convenient location.  
<Date>Apr 23, 2007

<Author>stckgo
<Content>Nice, Friendly The grounds were very nice, the staff very accommodating and friendly. The food and drinks were very expensive ($7.50 for a Shirley Temple!!) The Italian Restaurant was very good and they have a very reasonable kids menu. If you drink beer, buy it at the mini-mart across the street. Take a cab into Old San Juan to eat, even with the cost of the cab it's still less expensive than eating at the hotel. If you're staying in the towers there's a free continental breakfast on the second floor that they don't advertise (I think it's supposed to be for executive travellers and/or memebers of their diamond club but your room key will give yoou access.)

<Author>ellenok
<Content>We loved the Caribe Hilton! My family and I have just returned, reluctantly, from a week at the Caribe Hilton. We had a wonderful and relaxed week, with consistently excellent service, beautiful food, and comfortable surroundings. We arrived after midnight and checked into a room on the Executive level of the main building. Our room was simply decorated, with the most comfortable beds I have ever slept in. Even though we were traveling on Hilton points, we had complimentary chocolates and Evian waiting for us. The room was clean, but the carpets and upholstered furniture were rather worn and water-stained, and the room was a bit small for two adults and two teenagers. The next day, we stopped by the HHonors desk and asked if there were a larger room available. Our request was handled with grace and efficiency by Mr. Luis Sanchez ?he moved us into an enormous one bedroom suite at the top of the Garden building. We quadrupled our space!The Hilton is not new, and there are areas that are in need of updating. Both our first and our upgraded room had need of a bit of attention (a missing drawer pull, a shower fixture that squirted a bit), but we were clear that we were spending a week, not moving in, and had a clean and comfortable place to sleep and change and have a bit of down time. Our room was immaculately cleaned daily, with an abundance of towels. The furniture was colorful and comfortable and again, the bed was sublime.Unlike the previous reviewer, we had a beautiful meal at Morton. Our dinner at Lemongrass was phenomenal. We also thought the tapas at Madrid were rather uninspired, although the service was friendly, helpful, and speedy. Even the cheeseburgers at the poolside restaurant, Atlantico, were excellent. And the fruit! Lovely fresh fruit salads everyday. We generally skipped breakfast, and waited for poolside lunches at 11:00. When we needed breakfast, however, the HHonors lounge continental spread was sufficient. Room service breakfast one early morning was expensive, but VAST ?two orders more than fed four of us. We only enjoyed the buffet dinner at Palmeras once, and found it excellent ?with possibly the best lamb chops (chuletas) I have ever had. Yes, the food  beverage service is relatively expensive, but anyone who lives or travels in New York will find this Hilton no steeper. The drinks were $8, but wee paying more than $10 in New York (and even Providence) restaurants. Considering that we were traveling on Hilton points, we were happy to pay for good food and drinks.The grounds, gardens, pools, and beach are all beautiful and well cared for. I was dubious about the beach, since it looks very small in all the photos I saw, but I was pleasantly surprised to find it big enough, with plenty of room to drift off on a raft without bumping anyone. Most people seemed to prefer the pools, which were also big enough for all of us.I could go on and on, but suffice it to say, I be happy to return to the Caribe Hilton, even without points!  
<Date>Apr 22, 2007

<Author>kja2007
<Content>Overall good My fiance and I recently went to San Juan looking for a place to stay when we return to get married this summer. The Caribe Hilton is near Old San Juan, has several restaurants, a sizeable private beach, a multilevel pool with swim-up bar, nice ocean views, and a cool inner courtyard. Overall, we were very happy with it. We were able to have some romantic moments around the property, while others enjoyed being there in family groups or for business meetings. It does a pretty good job overall of balancing the various desires of these often quite different groups.We stayed in a ground-level room in the Garden wing. It was a nice room, well-kept etc., but I would have liked to have had an outdoor patio, which the room didn't have. It was quiet and well-kept.The restaurant we really loved was Lemongrass. It has really good Asian-Fusion food and a cool decor right on the inner courtyard of the hotel - bubbling water, bug and frog sounds at night, etc. Other than that, the morning buffets were good. And we liked the swim-up bar - their drinks were good, and the music was also better than elsewhere in the pool area. The pool area casual food bar (I believe it was called Atlantic) was okay on the one time we ate there. Whatever you do, eat as much of the fresh fruit as you can - I didn't have any that wasn't really good!The pools themselves were nice, with an adequate amount of chairs situated throughout the pool and beach area, as well as a few hammocks. They even have a separated area for pool games, so those who want to play water volleyball aren't bonking others in the head with their volleys, which we appreciated. They also had a small side kiddie pool, which is nice for those with kids (we don't have any).A little warning about going into Old San Juan: the cabs are $10 across the board in Old San Juan - they go by zones. So although you may only be going from the very edge of Old San Juan back to the hotel, expect to pay $10 (plus gratuity). We had to just deal with that and remember that it's still cheaper than renting a car and parking it at the hotel parking garage! On some maps it looks like a very short walk into Old San Juan - it's probably about 2 1/2 miles, though, not the 1/2-3/4 of a mile it looked like on one map we saw. Just a caution, so you know what the distance is.A tip for the pale ones among us: don't even THINK of going outside without sunscreen, even for a short time, even in the spring! I was outside for a whopping 20 minutes before I remembered to put on sunblock, and I got relatively burned (mild peeling on my shoulders).As far as expense, the hotel is a bit pricey, but it's mostly worth it for all the stuff to do right on the property and within easy reach of a short car trip. That makes it a good choice for those who are looking to just hang out at the hotel and relax, so you don't need to go searching for things to do or places to eat every day.Overall, I think the hotel does a good job of presenting something for everyone, and making it easy to relax and wind down at the hotel.  
<Date>Apr 17, 2007

<Author>Luv2TravelNewJersey
<Content>Nice stay We recently returned from a 6 night stay at the Caribe Hilton (3/30-4/5). Wife and I took our two young children. We arrived around 1PM and were told our room was not ready yet (official check in time is 4PM) and were given a phone number to call to check up on room status during wait. Room was ready at 3PM and we were upgraded to an ocean front room in the tower building which was a pleasant surprise since I did not bother to ask for an upgrade seeing as the hotel was fully booked. Room in the tower building was very modern and clean with a flat screen TV and large bathroom. Only ding on room was there was no bathtub (instead a very large shower) which prefer for the little ones. As mentioned in prior reviews, the grounds are very nice. I found the staff on the whole very friendly and accomadating as well. Our package (booked through a travel agent) included complimentary breakfast. The breakfast buffet was one of the better ones I have seen compared to other hotels in this class and price range. The Lemongrass restaurant located on the property was outstanding. As a comparison, we stayed four years ago in PR at the Marriott Stelaris. Would give the Hilton higher marks on grounds, pool and private beach. Marriott's main advantage is that it is right in the heart of Condado so you can walk right out the door and hit restaurants and shopping. The Hilton is fairly isolated with only a Subway and small convenience store located near. On the whole, both hotels provide for good family vacation.  
<Date>Apr 12, 2007

<Author>TravelBugMaryland
<Content>For laying out, this place couldn't be more convenient, but... If you are looking to just lay in the sun, then this place is great. They have plenty of chairs, towels and choices: a small strip of beach sand, several pool areas, and a breezy section overlooking the ocean. Everything in the resort is very convenient: they have several places to eat (expect to pay resort prices), a swim-up bar (again, resort prices!), a Starbucks, a center to check your email, etc. So for sunbathing and relaxing, this place is great. If your looking for a more cultural, ethnic trip then being out at the resort could be a bit of a hassle. For a real taste of San Juan, you need to get outside the resort and go into Old San Juan (about a 10 minute drive). There you find more of the food and flavor of the area. Cabbing back and forth can add up quickly, but driving there is even more expensive with valeting and city parking -- plus the driving there is a little crazy -- confusing and fast-paced -- even for this city driver!. And the potholes! I thought I bottomed out the rental car twice. The spa is fair -- my massage was good -- but my facial, pedicure and maincure were barely adequate -- but if you are a big spa-goer who is used to first rate spa treatments, I'd pass on this spa and spend your time relaxing in the sun.  
<Date>Apr 11, 2007

<Author>judyjackson
<Content>Great place for families! My husband and our four children ages 10-15 stayed here during spring break. The bay/beach area is perfect for children. There are no waves, since there is a break wall far out. The hotel offers snorkel equipment, kayaks and waterbikes. The area is calm and safe enough to let your kids use the equipment (all for a price) alone, as long as they can swim. The pool is beautiful with waterfall and swim up bar. There is also a hot tub. There is plenty of room on the beach, around the pool and in the hammock area to set up for your day. We stayed in the Villas and the rooms were roomy and the bathrooms recently remodeled (marble vanities, double sinks, sepate toilet area). There is also a separate pool and hot tub for the Villas which the kids went to only in the evening. The hotel food was average, but the beach/pool area more than made up for it. Service was excellent, rooms were cleaned everyday by 10:00am, and front desk, valet and bellhops were all polite, helpful and friendly! I would go back again in an instant!!  
<Date>Apr 9, 2007

<Author>JenandDennis
<Content>Perfect Location/Nice Place Your stay at the Caribe all depends which room you stay in. I read the reviews fearing we were going to be put in a moldy/dirty room, so I called a week before and requested to stay in the Honors Tower. Thank goodness they followed up on our request. It was a very nice room. It had a flat screen, a nice balcony, an awesome frameless, tile shower and a very comfortable king bed. It seems the garden rooms aren't as nice and may need rennovation.The lobby is gorgeous. The pool area is beautiful. The beach is the only private beach on the island for a hotel. The Olas spa was excellent! I had a facial.This hotel is a perfect location if you want to explore a bit. It is 12 minutes from the airport. It is 10 minutes from Old San Juan. 10 minutes from Condado and 15 minutes from Isla Verde. The cab fare gets very expensive so try the bus or walk. The bus is 50 to 75 cents, one way. The walk to Condado is about 20 to 25 minutes.Just a note, the whole island shuts down on Good Friday and Easter, so when you plan your vacation be aware.  
<Date>Apr 8, 2007

<Author>auntbuff
<Content>Thoroughly enjoyed my stay at the Caribe Hilton This hotel was recommended to me by friends. I'll be back!I stayed in the Honors Tower, the first room I was taken to didn't have quite the view I was looking for - but the bellman and the desk people very quickly assigned me to another room. I believe it was an ocean deluxe.The view was astounding, I was able to see the pools, 2 old forts, the harbor  ocean all from my room  balcony. The sun came up on the side of the hotel where I was staying  I found myself getting up a couple of hours earlier than usual just to see the sunrise!Staff was friendly, helpful and courteous.Loved the pool area, the hammocks (be sure to put a towel down before laying on the hammocks in a bathing suit! I forgot  got rope burns on my back!)There is plenty within walking distance, and so much on the grounds of the hotel itself. It was a great central location, a short drive from Old San Juan. I could go on . . . but I would find myself wanting to hop back on a plane  check in!

<Author>McLeanMommy
<Content>Great Family Hotel My husband and I took our two oldest (of 4) children on a spring break trip to San Juan to enjoy the beach, learn some history, and practice our Spanish. The beaches of San Juan are comparable to those of southern (Miami) Florida, with nice sand and clear water. We experienced some of Puerto Rico's prettiest beaches on a day trip to the offshore isle of Culebra, which has little to recommend it other than its beautiful sand and waters.San Juan's history -- especially the old Spanish fortifications -- is interesting, if a bit underwhelming. The nearby rainforest of El Yunque National Park was certainly beautiful, though not quite as spectacular as I had expected. That said, both old San Juan and El Yunque offer quick, easy, and interesting diversions if you do not want to spend all day at the beach.The people of Puerto Rico were very kind and accomodating and one young man gave us a friendly and free ride back to San Juan from Fajardo (1 hour +) one disastrous evening (long story).When my husband and I travel without children we stay at the Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton and Mandarin Oriental hotels, so we are accustomed to good hotels. However, when we travel with our kids we try to stay at hotels that have nice pools, good activities and a lot of space. The Hilton El Caribe was wonderful on all counts.The rooms themselves are best described as perfectly standard and good business-class hotel accomodations. Our room -- a King Garden Suite (# 843) -- consisted of two connecting rooms. Each room had its own entry door, work area, mini refridgerator, safe, telephone, television and balcony. The main room had a king-size bed (quite comfortable), a full bathroom (standard), and a spacious and separate entry foyer. The second room had a full-size, pullout sofabed and a half bathroom. Pleasantly, our rooms had views of the old Fort San Geronimo (on site) and the ocean, and importantly, we experienced absolutely no daytime or evening noise.The El Caribe's grounds are quite lovely and especially fun for kids. There is a large main pool, subdivided into separate pool areas with waterfalls, or a basketball hoop, a bar, or hot tubs. The Condado Villas have a separate, more secluded and smaller pool area with its own hot tub. We generally retreated to that pool area to relax at the end of the day.The hotel has a private, man-made beach with fronts a clear, calm and small little inlet. The calm, inlet ocean water has waterslides and you can rent little boats.In addition, the El Caribe's grounds have a large carp, goldfish and koi pond. There are basketball and shuffleboard areas. There is a small children's playground. There is a pier where you can feed and observe fish in the open the ocean day or night. There are chessboards and other outdoor games scattered throughout the place. For adult relaxation, there is a nice health club, outdoor morning yoga classes, three outdoor bars, lounge chairs everywhere (on the beach, by the pool, facing the ocean pier) and hammocks in a lovely grove of palm trees. The is an onsite rental car agency (Hertz), and travel tour company (didn't use it).Finally, the El Caribe has many on-site restaurant choices (though we usually went offsite), including the truly good and relaxing Lemongrass, as well as a Starbucks coffee, Morton's steak house, Madrid tapas, and a standard hotel restaurant which hosts a breakfast buffet (kids are free) and dinner every day.The hotel's location is convenient, fifteen minutes to the airport and five minutes to Old San Juan. In short, the Hilton El Caribe -- opened as the El Caribe in 1949 -- is as good a place to stay in San Juan as any, especially with children. I would certainly stay there again if I ever return to San Juan.  
<Date>Apr 3, 2007

<Author>staceyglow
<Content>One star room in 5-star surroundings First of all, I will state up front that I booked this hotel room through Hotwire. Because I know I am paying possibly the lowest rate in the entire hotel (which was still quite a bit of money), I don't expect the best room they have. However, I do expect to have a room at the quality level that they have promised Hotwire (which was 4 stars). I have used Hotwire on quite a few other occasions, and this has never been a problem before now. People reading this review should know that I am not one of those TripAdvisor members that appear to be chronic complainers; I don't like to let minor annoyances or inconveniences ruin my vacation, and this is the first negative travel review that I have ever written.My family and I arrived at the Hilton Caribe and I was extremely impressed by the gorgeous grounds and the beautiful lobby. An employee offered us complimentary chilled bottles of water as we checked in. I made a mental note to tell my father, a Hilton Honors Diamond level member, that this might be the place he may want to spend some of his accumulated points.Then we were shown to our room. My jaw dropped. This is a four-star hotel room? Frankly, I have had Motel 6 rooms that were nicer. The seams in the carpet were raveling. The curtain rod for the sheers had pulled out of the drywall and was hanging cock-eyed. While the view contained some lovely tropical plants, it was primarily of a side of a building covered by rust stains and dripped paint. Even though the square footage of the bathroom was rather large, it only contained a tiny, fiberglass modular shower unit (no tub) and a stand-alone single vanity. Both of them looked like very cheap Home Depot cash-and-carry fixtures. If were were staying more than one night, and my family hadn't been exhausted from our travel, I would have asked for a different room. I joked to my husband that this was probably not the room Paris stays in when she visits this hotel!I should also add that my room was accross the hall from a room that had the ice machine and the service elevator. The door to this room had extremely squeaky hinges (do they not have WD-40 in Puerto Rico?), and all night long I was treated to the loud squeaking of the door hinges and the dinging of the service elevator whenever it reached our floor (which, being the main floor, was often.).Let me say that the facilities are beautiful. This hotel is out on a nice point of land, and they have a gorgeous pool area and a beach that has a reef further out that calms the waves before they hit the swimming area.Besides the Starbucks(for breakfast the next morning). the only meal that we ate there was lunch at their outdoor bar and grill. Warning: if you are watching your budget, pay attention to your beverages. Our family had a meal of 3 chicken tender baskets, a hot dog, 2 pina coladas, 2 virgin pina coladas, and 4 soft drinks, and the bill before tip was $92.00. Turns out that that the virgin pinas were $7.50 each (they only charge you a buck more for the booze) and the cokes were $3.25 each . I realize that this is the typical prices one pays at a big-city Hilton, but they were the highest by far I had paid for drinks anywhere else in the Caribbean. I guess that going forward, I am going to have to decide whether to look cheap and ask the drink prices ahead of time or just order with my fingers crossed and hope for the best.My advice? This looks like a nice place to stay if you get a good room (I'd ask to see it first, and make sure it is in one of the newer buildings) and you can afford it. The next time we are in San Juan, our family will be exploring other options.  
<Date>Apr 3, 2007

<Author>Drifting_clouds
<Content>Expensive but enjoyable We stayed at this hotel 2 nights before a cruise and enjoyed our stay. The price is quite steep at $270 night base rate but we did like the room and setting very much.Having read mixed reviews on this web site after we booked, we did call the hotel several days in advance directly as I have allergies and was concerned about getting a damp or mildewed room after seeing some reviews which mentioned this. We mentioned that fact to the clerk. Perhaps that accounted for the fact that when we went to check in the clerk told us we had been upgraded to a room in the tower on the top floor. It was a very nice room with a great balcony view. We enjoyed the small beach they have and spend most of one day just being there and in the pleasant water....much nicer beach than that of the Marriott which has big waves and wasn't very clean or pleasant to be in. The Hilton had a nice quiet beach with no wave action. Very nice just to float on the peaceful waters. The grounds are very nice too. Pools are attractive but not connected so you really have 3 small/medium size pools right next to each other. Lots of people all over encamped in beach chairs. Food was expensive so we ate breakfast both mornings at the small health food cafe at the spa area which is not as pricey. Spoke to 3 different concierges and all were helpful.  
<Date>Apr 1, 2007

<Author>CeeGee
<Content>Real relaxation Stayed mid-March with my teenage daughter for 5 days and booked a Spa Package. The manicure, pedicure, facial and massage were a definite treat. As HH members, we had an Executive Tower room, which was very nicely appointed. The staff at the hotel was friendly and helpful, especially with restaurant reservations. A definite bonus was the use of the Executive Lounge with complimentary snacks and beverages and free Internet (15 minutes pp). I was a bit disappointed that the HH Lounge had a cash bar. I've been to other Hiltons where they offered free cocktails. Yes, the $$ spent on cabs to and from Old San Juan added up, but the total was comparable to a car rental ($45 /day). We also used the gym (also nice). We had coupons for the breakfast buffet (great), lunch in the Olas Health Bar and a light supper in the Madrid Tapas Bar. Otherwise, we dined in Old San Juan and Condado. Try Races for native cuisine. Overall, this was a relaxing getaway that perfectly suited our needs.

<Author>cheryl42255
<Content>room problems, great pool and grounds We stayed in a room with a great view over looking the ocean and pool area. The room itself smelled damp and extremely musty. Even with the sliding door open to the balcony the smell stayed. The bathroom tub did not drain after one shower, we had 4 of standing water, the towel bar was hanging, our bed was not made as it should have been. We only had a bottom sheet and a bedspread - no top sheet or blankets. We called maintenance to fix the bathroom before 5 pm saying we would be out for dinner and if possible please fix while we were out. We came back at 8 and nothing was done. I had to call again and they came up within a half hour. They fixed the bathtub drain, the towel bar and remade the bed properly. Upon checking in the people at the front desk were great. Upon checking out early on Saturday the person at the front desk totally ignored me for at least 5 minutes - he should be fired. When I complained about the room all he said was sorry to hear that. This hotel seems to spend a lot of time keeping up the outdoor area which is fantastic.

<Author>livetotravelPA
<Content>mostly pleasant We stayed at the Caribe Hilton for three nights, 3/15-18. We have concluded that room assignment is highly variable and a big determinant of how reviewers have rated the hotel. We spent our first night in the main building. Had we been forced to stay in that room- our trip would have been VERY disappointing. Old, worn, dated, cracks, etc. I would expect more from a Motel 6! Fortunately- we moved to the Honors Tower. Beautiful! And- since we were on the side facing Old San Juan and the ocean- it was very quiet... we did not hear ANY construction noise. It is unfortunate that within the same resort there is such variability in the quality of rooms, noise level, quality of concierge service, bar service, etc. In one case the concierge was very helpful... when someone else was at the desk- it might as well have been vacant, since NO real assistance was provided. Housekeeping was adequate- but they removed my towel which was hanging on the bathroom door hook (a chamois I bring when I travel since I often react to the detergents hotels use). Management did nothing and did not return our calls to discuss a resolution. Bell service was OK- but they store luggage in a roped area of the open air lobby... not secure at all! On the positive side- the beach area is NICE! It was a pleasant haven- quieter than around the bar area and much less windy. We thoroughly enjoyed Lemongrass and Madrid-San Juan. Drink service was a mixed bag... SLOW service and not necessarily tasty pina coladas- which originated at this hotel!Overall we had a nice time in SJ and plan to return... we will likely stay elsewhere- ESJ, Ritz Carlton or the Westin. We were unable to fit in a trip to the rainforest so we'll likely stay closer to that area than Old San Juan next time.  
<Date>Mar 24, 2007

<Author>socprof
<Content>Avoid until construction is done I've been to this hotel before and liked it in the past. As other reviewers have pointed out, the location is amazing, given the hotel's private beach and that it is much closer to old san Juan than similar beachfront hotels in Isla Verde. However, the Caribe Hilton is in the midst of constructing a new addition and it is VERY LOUD (from around 7 am to 6 pm). There are many hotel rooms that are affected by the noise. Being awoken by construction noise, being unable to use the patio, and not being able to take an afternoon nap all negatively affected my attempt to have a relaxing vacation at the Caribe Hilton.

<Author>withliberty
<Content>Nice - but Nickel and Dimed Overall, this is an above average hotel, but the bill was truly a nickel and dime experience. A daily resort fee of $20+ was added with occupancy taxes for added insult. When I went in person to the business center to complain that I couldn't seem to get Internet access via the room's modem, the gentleman politely ushered me into a room with access. Then, he charged me $5 for 15 minutes. Plus occupancy taxes! Private beach was great, ocean views are great, location is great. Service was good, but not 5 star. The Hilton is literally right next door to the Normandie, so I explored that hotel for comparison and would say the Hilton's amenities appear much better (beach, swimming pools, restaurants, etc.). Only real bad news was that there was some type of raw sewage pouring out from the driveway on more than one day - not appetizing if you are about to spend $$$ at Morton's Steakhouse. Instead, head up the street to El Hamburguer for the best $3 burger on the planet.

<Author>steadyhand98
<Content>Perfect Location Beautiful Spot If you are going to stay in or near San Juan this the hotel to stay in...Worth every penny..It has its own beach, a clean calm lagoon which is great for kids, (95% of the hotels in San Juan area do not have their own beach, they use public access beaches which are ok but not great) a very good Gym, beautiful swimming pools. (.one with a swim up bar,) very good food, and nice rooms. The hotel bars are excellent..This is where the Pina Colada was invented back in th 50's..The staff is bend over backwards friendly...The rooms are on the small side but not that big a deal since the weather is the main attraction..Views are beautful..If you call ask about the executive lounge feature..It sounds hoity toity but actually it gives you lots of free food options..It might only come with certain floors so ask first how you can get this included with the room price Renting a car is not necessary, as cabs are the best way to go anywhere,.Bus service is non existent...Old San Juan is charming with cobble stone streets and an immense Fort..Beautful lit up at night..There are some eyesores in and around San Juan but if you look past them you will see a certain charm in this area...Try walking to the Coronada area to the east of the hotel along the water and you will find a couple of cafes that have waves that come right up to the windows. We ate breakfast there...Be prepared to spend money on food as this is expensive in this part of Puerto Rico...even just basic lunch food. is high..The Hilton actually had healthy lunch type food that was somewhat less expensive than a lot of the local eateries we tried..Good veggie food cooked by locals is in the Hilton Gym cafe which is hidden away for some reason by the tennis courts..Take a cab ride to Isle Verde one evening and walk through some mega expensive hotel lobbies like the El San Juan which is spectacular(with a casino) and the Ritz Carlton..Good Mexican food sports bar called Lupis in this area..If you like snorkling take the catamaran ( you can book this in the hotel lobby) tour..It goes to an unpopulated Island off the coast .. right out of a post card..Even if you don't snorkle, the ride is great. the water warm,,...

<Author>Sunlover5
<Content>Great Experience We received this hotel for 75.00 a night for our precruise stay from Feb. 22-25, 07. (we were not tacked on any extra charges, like resort fees.) We arrived at 3, our room was ready right at 4:00. Very nervous as both workers at the desk kept saying oh what a wonderful room you got!! I told my husband I think they were trying to convince us it was a great room before we saw it!!!Well, It WAS a great room. We were in the Condado Villas. #7117. Kitchen, bath, king bed, beautiful big terrace with loungers and boy what a view!!! Thought maybe we would get a lousy room since got it so cheap--glad I was wrong. Very clean room, great maid service.Only one problem, our safe wouldn't work, needed a new part, and Carlos fixed it right on the spot!!!!!!!Food is high priced, but the day we were on the beach, my husband and I split a hamburg and fries. They were huge so we had plenty.The garden rooms hallway smelled musty. The rooms looked ok, but I would have been disappointed if we would have gotten one. No view either.Did not ever eat supper there, went to town. The bus is easy to use for only 1.75. We had breakfast at the Subway right out the front of the hotel. Pancakes, breakfast sandwiches, french toast. and the right price!!!!I would definitely stay here again, and we loved our 3 day stay!!!!

<Author>Liverneck
<Content>Enjoyed the Caribe Hilton Just spent 5 nights at the Caribe Hilton in Feb 2007. Overall we had a very good time. The staff is very nice and accomodating. The Spanish/Puerto Rican restaurant was excellent. The Buffet breakfast at the hotel restaurant was also excellent. The beach and pool were a lot of fun for the kids (and adults). However this is not a 5 star hotel. The rooms were a little run down. The refrigerator was not working and we were told that they are room temperature refrigerators by the staff. This is laughable and unacceptable for a resort hotel in 2007. Nevertheless I would stay there again.

<Author>WorldTravelerNYC123j
<Content>Screaming Kids, High Prices, Poor Service  I spent two nights in the Caribe Hilton and was quite disappointed. I booked an executive level room and expected to stay on the executive level. Upon check in, I was put on a standard floor (6th floor) instead of the executive level floors 9th and 10th. When I asked why they said that the hotel was fully booked. I later found out that they will sell an executive level room to anyone that is willing to pay an extra $100 dollars and then stick you in a normal room with access to the executive level lounge. The room that I was given on the 6th floor was noisy, dirty and quite old looking. The bathroom had rust stains all over the bath tub, walls and plaster falling from the ceiling. The carpet is well worn and needs to be replaced. When I got into the bed I discovered someone else hair on the sheets (Disgusting). When I tried to fall asleep I was kept awake by noise coming from the room above me. After I complained twice to the desk the hotel security finally took care of the problem. The next morning when I went to the executive level lounge for breakfast I was greeted with utter chaos. There must have been 150 people in an executive level lounge made to hold 25 people at the most. In addition to that there were plenty of screaming kids running around making lots of noise (I thought this was supposed to be an executive level lounge not a day care center). The breakfast selection was lacking. I also later found out that the complimentary beverages during happy hour are no longer complimentary (Cash Bar). This is the first executive level lounge that I have ever been in that charges you for a beer.The pool area is probably the high light of this hotel. Nice large pools and a beach area. The only downside is a million screaming kids. Service at this hotel is definitely lacking. The staff is very slow and makes no effort to help you. Just to get a waiter to take your order can take upwards of 1 hour in one of the hotels restaurants.The bottom line:OverpricedPoor ServiceDirty Rooms that are falling apartScreaming kids Executive Lounge is a ripe-offThe next time I in San Juan I will stay at the Ritz Carlton  
<Date>Mar 1, 2007

<Author>gjsny
<Content>Ritz prices for lacklustre service I agree with the prior review. We also stayed in the Lagoon Villas at the recommendation of the hotel as we explained before hand we were a family and needed space. The rooms were NY boutique small. The prices are very high for what you get. We were quoted $265 a night but after taxes and valet parking fee it was closer to $399 a night. Plus we found out people at the same rate had breakfast included while we were charged $20 per person for the buffet. Add that in and you are well over $400 per night for what is a very crowded and understaffed mid range hotel. We had no movie service in our room the entire stay despite reporting it daily to the front desk and the malfunctioning electronic rooms keys were a common pain for everyone. All the restaurants on the property are expensive for the quality.On the plus side the staff/people are friendly, it has a great location and its close to Old San Juan. The concierge desk is overworked but very useful and the free wireless network access at the in premises Starbux a bonus!

<Author>dietzberger
<Content>A great concept, but is it worth the money? We spent two nights at the start of a week in Puerto Rico in February, with two pre-teen children. It's a handsome place, nicely conceived and beautifully set--we wanted to be near Old San Juan. But for the prices at high season we would have expected better. The room, in the newest wing (Lagoon Villas) was attractive, but far too crowded for the price, and there was inadequate closet space for two people much less four. We wanted to eat at the chic Asian-fusion Lemongrass restaurant, set in one of the courtyards by our wing, but it was booked for a private party (a wedding reception), which went on and on very loudly, keeping us all up until (get this!) the cops shut it down way after midnight. The pools are lovely, and the beach is nice (for play, not for anything else); and we found all of the service very nice, if not always very efficient. I wouldn't have minded any of the problems had we not been paying enormous prices (as high as Disney World--where you get your money's worth).  
<Date>Feb 25, 2007

<Author>SunandBoards
<Content>Caribe was great The Caribe is a big hotel, and a good location if you want close access to the airport and old san juan. I visited with my wife and two kids, 9 and 12.For the kids, I think this is a really fun spot, since they have a nice pool complex, and easy access to the ocean. You can snorkel in the bay, see some cool fish, or just stay closer to shore near the water toys. The pool complex might get boring after 3 or 4 days, but otherwise it is nice. The Caribe has a ton of loungers all over the beach complex, close to pools, to beach, to palm trees, etc. and that variety was great.For my wife and I, we liked the broad range of restaurants on site. They are expensive, so we liked to take our time, which doesn't always work with kids. Fortunately, my kids were happy to get take-out Subway grinders and eat in the room watching disney channel movies, which is a rare treat for them. This freed up my wife and I to enjoy a 2 hour meal right on the hotel grounds. Our favorite was Lemongrass, since it is set in the garden and perfect for outdoor dining.The staff at the business center were very accomodating and proficient. The concierge staff certainly tried hard, but my experience was mixed, since once they sent us to a local museum without noticing that the museum wasn't open on that day. The room decor, at least in the garden wing, felt dated, but housekeeping kept it tidy.

<Content>Decent Hotel BUT THE SERVICE STINKS My wife and I went down for the Presidents Weekend the hotel was great until Saturday when EVERYONE else showed up. <Author>travelingsweet70
<Content>A+ for Paris' Dad You can look at this hotel in a couples of ways that can sway your star rating but here are a couple of observation I had when my husband and I traveled to the caribe hilton earlier this Feb.1. Your best bet for a relaxing vacation is always choosing the best room you can get. (remember this resort is one of the oldest in san juan...so new areas have been built some rooms upgraded and redesigned...you can have a low floor, high floor) I think the rooms can vary at caribe hilton this can sway your rating....our room was great with great view2. Your in san juan area if your looking just to stay on el caribe premisses that have a little built up laggon area, a number of pools, a shopping plaza with a starbucks, clothing, shoes....so if you really want to stay put you could....but most people I would believe want to venture ot to old san juan or condado area....to see the scene or possilbly to go to a casino....in the neighboring area of condado...most of those hotels have them...el condado, marriott...etc...you could actually walk there but the bridge that connects caribe hilton area with condado area is a little dark at night to cross...i would cab it3. food there is a mortons on premises....also hilton breakfast buffet...was ok......if you not a morning person ...you can just goto starbucks...but if you plan on eating breakfast everyday try to get breakfast included...could be pricey if you don't.4. the hotel staff were excellent and there advice ...right on the money....they told us to go to a place for seafood named aquaviva in old san juan...when we were about to go exploring...the place was yummy...cerviche great...so were the oysters rockafeller...we even got to see an equestrian street show (just happened to be going on the weekend we visited) hole thing was delightful...we stumbled on a place called ropa vieja while walking in condado...was a great dinner!!!!5. the pools were clean and beautiful....be careful who you sit next to though....one women was on her cell loudly...talking about her stupid haphazard posting of her CV on monster.com...yap yap...and how she was getting job offers...new york ...penn....NJ...if your reading this and this was you....women you got to learn to be discreet...you were too...loud...we didn't need to know your business but man we had no chioce....lol...(sorry I got off track :o) back to my review): 6. Bar areas.....very nice.....even to just check out....big screen tv indoors near main lobby...great......live music....greatwe didn't mind paying for our liquor (were from NY and bars can be pricey)BUT so people doing this (tip: drinks expensive: Get plastic cups from bar (buy a drink, keep cup) then store bears liquor in your room that you bought from airport or from shops, groceries stores (not many in the area so try to find some when your getting there or out and about otherwise you will need transportation to get to a place that has it at a good price). 7. Great location-If you stay in isla verde where a majority of the hotels are....you will have to deal with the noise of the airport...very very loud I saw reviews where for a couple of seconds you can't hear your own conversations......caribe hilton was in a perfect location....further away from airport.....only heard prop planes from small airport in the area and that was occasional.8.Room service -yummy9. history - this hotel has history...thats why the have so much grounds becuase they had this area for so long...most hotels don't have so much area---as you can tell by the fort on the premisses with nice views of ocean crashing on rocks...there is a view of the lagoon...there is a small beach area...very diverse...the grounds are well kept and they have a beautiful veranda area with swans...very peacefulThis hotel definetly is what you make of it and your trip...If you get a nice room, happen to have great weather and go exploring...youll get the best out of this hotel...Happy travels!!!! Hasta la vista!!!!

<Author>2fromMass
<Content>Beautiful views, so-so service, 'cruise-shippy' First off, I should make a disclaimer...we're not resort/cruise people; we love small boutique hotels and tend to be a bit biased against big resort properties. Still, I think we could both see the virtues and faults of the Caribe Hilton (and this was only 2 nights of a 2-week Carribean vacation). We picked it because I have oodles of Hilton points from business travel and we were attracted to the location between Old San Juan and Condado, the two areas where we were considering staying.The hotel gave us a very nice ocean-facing room with a balcony (perhaps because of my diamond status with Hilton.). The room was clean and seemed recently renovated. The beds were extremely comfortable. The A/C was way too cold, and despite changing the thermostat, it only seemed to stop cranking out cold air when we turned it all the way off. The view of the ocean, Fort San Geronimo, and over to Condado was spectacular. The hallways, on the other hand, had a fair amount of peeling paint, etc. Perhaps more renovations are on their way?The setting is beautiful... a scenic beach (on a lagoon, not the open ocean), lots of palm trees, a curvy walkway along the ocean's edge, etc. Adjacent Fort San Geronimo added a nice touch to our view. Too bad it seems to be permanently closed. Despite the beautiful location, the overall atmosphere is way to cruise-shippy for our tastes (shuffleboard, etc.). As soon as the sun came down each night, the bar (located in the open-air lobby) featured a loud lounge singer and back-up musicians whose Vegas-meets-Carribean sound echoed throughout the lobby and outdoor areas).The location--which we had predicted would be a key positive aspect--was in some ways minus. Although it's between Old San Juan and Condado, it's actually a bit far of a walk to either, requiring a $20 taxi (for about a 2 mile trip?!!) to get to most restaurants and nightlife. The sheer size of this sprawling complex--a plus for many, I'm sure, was a bit of a minus for us. It made us feel a bit detached from the rest of the city.The service was mixed. While we were waiting in the long Hilton Honors check-in line, a helpful staff member directed us to another check-in location, at the HHonors tower (named as an attempt to make us feel special, I suppose). The service was incredibly slow at the bars and restaurants. We ordered food service on our first night. Don't do it! Our chicken quesadilla was late, cold, flavorless, and overpriced. The executive lounge had a great view, but was packed at breakfast and the staff couldn't keep up with clearing dishes and replenishing supplies. They also cleared all of the food out immediately at 11 am (closing time), which we found particularly annoying since we had spent the last 15 minutes chasing down staff to replenish the already near-depleted supply of food as well as bowls and plates to put the food on.The concierge was very helpful in providing us info and restaurant reservations. The turndown service was also a nice extra--not something I've found at most Hiltons.We'll probably pick somewhere else when we return to San Juan, but wouldn't be totally adverse to staying at the Caribe Hilton again to save money by using Hilton points (We were not particularly interested in the other Hilton family hotels in San Juan, since they are all loacted in Isla Verde--near the airport, an area of less interest to us.). The comfortable room and beautiful setting were the main plusses. I would not plan to have any meals there, though.  
<Date>Feb 10, 2007

<Author>bebebeck
<Content>Good location but poor service We stayed overnight at the San Juan Caribe Hilton on January 21, 2007. We were leaving on a cruise the next day. When we arrived at the hotel at 2:00 pm San Juan time, we were told that our room was not ready and that check in time was between 4:00 and 6:00 pm but that we could leave our luggage and wait in the lounge if we chose. We were starving so we went to the restaurant and literally stood there waiting for someone, anyone, to seat us. One of the already seated customers commented to us that it was the worse service she had ever seen. After going into the restaurant and hunting down a waiter and asking to be seated, we were told someone would be with us shortly. The restaurant was only about a third occupied. After being seated, we then waited for someone, anyone to take our order. Finally someone arrived and thirty more minutes later our sandwiches arrived. It was not just a one time occurance. We actually tried the restaurant again for lunch the next day and after waiting over 20 minutes for someone to take our order, after having asked for assistance, we got up and left. We went back to the service desk at 4:05 pm and were told that our room still was not ready. That sent my husband, a Hilton Honors member over the edge. He asked to speak to the manager and suddenly a room managed to be ready. Then we waited 2 more hours for our luggage to be sent to the room. It was only after we went back down to the bell station and reminded them that they had said they would deliver the luggage over 2 hours ago that they got around to getting it to the room. The room was in the remodeled tower of the hotel. The bed was comfortable. We had no washcloths in the bathroom. The pool area was nice and well kept. The service was deplorable. For a hotel as expensive as the Caribe, I expected much better.  
<Date>Feb 3, 2007

<Author>Ahip
<Content>mixed review A group meeting brought us to this hotel during the third week of January. I was a bit concerned about the stay having read previous reviews which were very mixed. First the bottom line. We have a very nice stay at the hotel but the room quality is definitely a potential issue. We arrived in the early afternoon and were assigned a room in the newly renovated tower. The air conditioning did not work well and there was no way to change it (preset at the high 60's F). The toilet leaked around the base, the balcony door had no lock, and there was a strange wire protruding from the floor by the balcony door. We were given a different room and everything was fine. As noted by others the beds are wonderful. This time the air conditioning (still preset) worked fine. The flat-screen TV was a nice touch. The remainder of our stay from a room standpoint was fine but you shouldn't have this kind of issue with a multi-star Hilton resort and if we'd arrived later in the day our room options would have been more limited. Food at the restaurant and elsewhere in San Juan is expensive unless you stay away from the restaurants frequented by tourists. You can easily spend $50 per person without drinks. On the other hand, I did grab lunch on the run at the Subway across the street one day for around $8.00. All in all, the location is not bad (a short cab ride into old San Juan) and aside from the initial room issues, I have no complaints. But....for the price and the hotel name we shouldn't have had the problems we did. Would I stay at this hotel again? Probably not since there are many 'name brands from which to choose.  
<Date>Jan 26, 2007

<Author>TravelDoc_DC
<Content>So-So Resort My husband and I stayed at the Caribe Hilton for 7 days. We were looking for a resort experience with the option to visit Old San Juan easily. While this resort had both of these, it was not special in any way.1) The room. The room which we reserved was in the Garden Tower. This tower is 8 stories and all rooms have a vew overlooking the birdsanctuary and if you are high enough, the ocean. While the view was lovely, the room was terrible. We should have known there was a problem when we opened the door and it was mildly warped. The room was damp and mildewy. Even the carpet was damp. It seems that our door to the balcony did not seal and the island humidity had gotten the best of our room. The hotel let us switch to the newer Tower that was recently renovated. It still had a view of the ocean but everything was dry and there was no musty odor. I suspect all of the Garden rooms are mildewy and would avoid that area.2) Restraunts. Not worth it. They are overpriced and the menus are not innovative. We wanted to eat at the resort but everytime we reviewed the menu, we were not inspired. There is so much fantastic food on the island, why waste time at a poor restraunt.3.) Water. The beach is pleasant enough with plenty of lounge chairs. There is a spot for everyone: the tanner, the relaxer, the family, the stay in the shade. However, don't bother renting the snorkel equipment as what remains of the coral in the area is near dead. The ocean, though clear, is too murky for snorkeling and there are not many fish in that area. The best place for viewing fish on the resort is at the fish feeding pier.We had a pleasant time as it was the closest resort with a beach to Old San Juan. However, we would not visit this resort again.  
<Date>Jan 21, 2007
<Rating>3	3	4	3	4	4	4	-1	
<Aspects>

<Author>gucci913
<Content>Caribe Hilton is Great My husband and I stayed at the Caribe Hilton last March for 4 nights with another couple and we had a fantastic time. We were a bit sceptical reading all of the reviews but we would definetely return.The hotel:The hotel is wonderful. It's located just a few minutes from the San Juan International airport. You wouldn't expect to see such a beautiful resort in the location but you'd be surprised. The open air lobby and and birds were such a nice touch. The lobby bar is quite trendy and a great place to end the evening. There are different areas to the hotel, execuitve and villas, and main area. We stayed in the Villas (not Villas at all), just a standard room which was quite small, but new and clean. Our view overlooked construction in the city but did not put a damper on the vacation at all.The pool  beach:The pool area was great and nicely landscaped. The property is on it's own secluded beach. But if you are looking for tropical blue water and white sand don't look for it here. It's a man made beach much like a lagoon, reminded me lot of a lake in NH. But none the less we enjoyed it very much because I was already aware of this when we booked our trip.The price was great and included breakfast buffet which was excellent. We didn't eat at any of the restaraunts for dinner because we wanted to venture out to the local places. There is however a few options including a Mortons and Lemon grass (which is surrounded by lush grounds and tropical birds).The area of San Juan is City like and very different from other areas we have been to in the Caribbean. But we would definetely return and opt to stay in the Hilton. I am a travel agent and saw many of the properties in the Condado area and a few nearby in Old San Juan. While there were other very nice properties in the area we would most likely return to the Hilton.Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or if you need any assistance planning your future trip. kmitchell@tripguy.com  
<Date>Jan 15, 2007

<Author>GailNorthCarolina
<Content>Timing is all We were at the Caribe Hilton in the post-New Year lull and at mid-week, and couldn't have found the service more gracious and helpful and smiling, nor the hotel more pleasant. The gardens and views of the 16th-century Spanish ruins that frame the property are stunning, and the grounds, well-shaded by palms and cooled by ocean breezes, were perfect for relaxing with a book in a hammock. The spa services are a plus and most of the restaurants about what you'd expect of a hotel chain resort hotel--with the exception of Lemon Grass, a jewel of a little Latino-pan-Asian restaurant, almost hidden in a tropical garden, where we ate some of the most delicious food we've ever eaten. (I had a dream about the homemade orange-ginger-cardamom ice cream). (It's a splurge and you'll need to book ahead, but Lemon Grass is well worth it). For real San Juan and authentic Puerto Rican food, the old city is a very short cab ride away, and taxis are always available. Be sure to try the little family-run La Fonda del Jibarito on Calle Sol for delicious local specialties. My main advice would be to avoid this hotel at over-crowded times like Christmas, New Year, and spring break weeks.  
<Date>Jan 14, 2007
