<Author>Balt0Traveler
<Content>Food Poisoning My family of 10 stayed at the Caribe Hilton for 2 nights before our criuse and 1 night after, which happened to be New Year's Eve. The Caribe Hilton is nice, but don't expect a sprawling resort like you get elsewhere in the Carribean. The resort itself consists of the buildings, a small garden, a nice pool and a small beach. It would probably take you only 5 minutes to take a tour of the whole place. It's surrounded by other large hotels and resorts. There's not a lot to do at the hotel due to the size. The beach is nice, but crowded, the pool was chilly and the hot tubs were jammed with kids. On our second night there my entire family ate at the buffet. They had a salad bar, taco stations, and desserts. At 4am the next morning both my brother and my neice woke up with horrible cases of food poisoning. We're not sure what they both ate, but we think it was the salad bar since my neice is a vegetarian and my brother is not. They both were completely incapacitated the next day. We alerted the hotel and they denied all responsibility. My mother had to call a doctor because they were both so ill. The doctor came to the resort and said he was stopping by numerous rooms to treat people with food poisoning. The hotel continued to deny all responsibility and made us pay the $300+ doctor bill. My mother requested a late checkout for my brother's room so we could take him straight to the cruise (we didn't want him to not have a bed and bathroom for a few hours) and the hotel gave it to him, but charged us. They even charged us for the dinner that made everyone sick! Once on the cruise we met several other groups who had the same situation at the Caribe Hilton. My neice recovered in a couple of days, but my brother was sick the entire week.All in all I wouldn't stay there again.  
<Date>Jan 12, 2007

<Author>utqiagvik
<Content>Generic, Bland, Characterless - As Far from Puerto Rico as Possible! Staying at the Caribe Hilton is like staying in Puerto Rico while being completely insulated from the island's magical flavor or culture. The feel was that of any generic chain resort in Florida or South Padre Island Texas, except that it cost 2-3 times a much, making Florida a much better value. We stayed there six nights around New Year's, and will not repeat the experience. It was like being on a cruise ship full of pushy tourists aggressively trying to squeeze out the maximum bang from their buck (imagine hordes of people tripping frantically over each other at 8AM to bag lounge chairs at the beach/pool area ... let's dump one shoe on this chair, one on the next, a towel on the next one, a magazine on the next, the guest services directory on the next ... you get the picture). As Gold HHonors members we had access to the executive lounge, where it was like pigs at the trough ... everytime a new platter of desserts or fruit or sandwiches came out, everyone rushes in to grab what they can. The front desk, belldesk, guest services, and concierge staff were totally disorganized (concierge put us on hold indefinitely on three occasions), harried-looking, and not too friendly (the last being totally uncharacteristic of the island). In fact, the local staff seemed to have had their Puerto Rican charm completely beat out of them, as if they were told to be as generic and robotic and culture-free as possible (like to give the impression of this is just like Omaha, honey!). The food at the restaurants was also completely generic, with precious little island flavor, and all the so-called local dishes we tried were completely watered-down versions (to quote Barbara Ehrenreich, like your regular Ohio cuisine with a tropical twist.) We ended up escaping into the city at regular intervals in order to avoid getting completely disheartened by how far this property is from everything that Puerto Rico represents (and also to meet some real locals and eat some real food). I think any of the hotels in the Condado or Old San Juan area would be much better bases for a tropical vacation with more Puerto Rican flavor ... the Caribe Hilton is as removed from the island as a cruise ship would be. Never again. Granted, the beach and pool area are nice, but one can get better beaches and better pools with far less crowds and at a fraction of the price in Florida. If one wants to go all the way to Puerto Rico, shutting oneself away in this generic, could-be-anywhere resort is a big mistake.  
<Date>Jan 11, 2007

<Author>WorldTravelerCO
<Content>Nice place, but very crowded We recently stayed at this hotel for one night, before our return home. We had originally booked the room for our first night in Puerto Rico, but our flight from the US was delayed. We were told by Expedia that our booking was non transferrable/refundable, but the hotel was understanding of our situation, which was out of our hands, and agreed to change our booking at no cost to us. What a relief!The hotel was nice, but very crowded. We waited quite a while to check in, only to find out that our room was not ready as promised. We were upgraded to a villa, which was lovely. Our villa neighbors were very noisy. Upon our complaint to the front desk, someone was sent to calm them down immediately and we had no further problems. I would probably look for a smaller, less crowded hotel the next time I am in San Juan, but the Hilton is lovely if you don't mind a crowd.

<Author>missbigcee
<Content>Beautiful Property-but don't eat there I stayed at the hotel with my boyfriend Dec 12th- Dec 16th. He was there for a conference so I sent alot of time by myself on the property. First, the pros. The property is beautiful, well kept. The housekeeping was excellent. I spent time at the pool, worked out at the gym and had no complaints in those areas. The service at the pool was friendly and efficient. Now to the cons, on the night we arrived we ordered room service, we needed to call room service not twice, not three times but FOUR times to pick up our tray. I live in NYC and dine at fine restaurants all the time. I thought that was a little on the ridiculous side. The last morning we were there, we had breakfast at the main restaurant and our eggs and oatmeal took 30 mintues to come out and when my eggs came out they were not made correctly. Stay in the hotel, but don't eat there is the moral here.

I did not feel the move but later realized that it was a group job. A person with a very small cute dog distracted my family asking them to pet it as I payed. On my way to the airport, calling the parking attendant booth did not provide any help, they refered me to hotel security, again, no help. They informed me that they have no cameras coveryng the parking booth area (?). Did not collect any info from me. -Local Police? Forget it! they're not even interested! I am still calling every day to ask if my wallet has been found. But with such an enthusiasm on their part, it seems I'm out of luck. --Never let your guard down.

<Author>midgetmama
<Content>Looks aren't everything I stayed here 12/19 and paid $65 on Priceline. I've been told there's absolutely no chance of upgrades when booking on Priceline and that I would be given the worst quality room. Luckily that wasn't true, and when I arrived I was given a room in the Condado Lagoon Villas.I was traveling with my mother, and she was shocked at how nice the room was after my repeated warnings that this may not be the greatest place due to what I paid for it. The room was large, we had a great view of the lagoon, and she took numerous pictures of the bathroom because she wants to model her own after it.The grounds are beautiful, and there is plenty to do on-site. The restaurants all sound and smell good but are a little pricey. Some menus don't have prices, the Italian restaurant averaged about $30-$40 for an entree, and Madrid-San Juan seemed the most reasonable, but of course it is a tapas place so most likely has small portions.We were very tired and didn't feel like getting ready to go out for dinner, so we ordered room service. I had the house salad, she had the Caesar, and we shared a margherita pizza. The house salad did not have croutons as described on the menu (I eat salad for the dressing and croutons, not the healthy stuff), and the croutons on the Caesar were tasteless and mushy. Other than that, the salads were very good. For some reason the pizza smelled like donuts, but it tasted like pizza and was surprisingly tasty. I also got the guava cheesecake which was fantastic. None of these things seemed too expensive on the menu, but after taxes and the automatic 15% gratuity, the total came to $56.39 which seemed a lot for what we got. But whatever.The main problems I had were in the bathroom. I turned one of the sinks on and left it running for a minute while I went to get some soap I had left by the bed. When I returned, the floor was covered in water due to leaky pipes. When I wiped it up with a towel, the towel ended up covered in brown dirt. I started checking other parts of the bathroom, and it seemed it was rarely cleaned. Also, throughout the room, there were black marks all over the floor and walls. It looked like crayons or scuff marks. Finally, there was a digital scale in the bathroom that didn't work! Now I certainly don't expect or care if there's a scale in my room, but what is the point of putting one in if it doesn't function?!Overall, the hotel, including the room I was in, was very beautiful, and the staff was all friendly and pleasant (contrary to what I expected from some of the reviews I've read), but they really ought to work a little harder on keeping the place clean and maintained. I've stayed in a lot of hotels, and cleanliness has never been an issue for me, so that part was disappointing. However, I would stay there again, especially at $65 a night!  
<Date>Dec 24, 2006

<Author>karena1
<Content>Fantastic, cannot say enough good about it Got to the Caribe Hilton about 5 to check in. I cannot say enough about this property and how they treated us. Understand - I don't demand 5 star hotels, but this place was so beautiful and the staff was so nice and friendly. Here are the highlights:1. Since it was my birthday, they upgraded us to Rm 1558 in the tower. Newly remodeled with a view that was gorgeous overlooking the water and the Condado district. Corner room which was really nice. Had a huge marble shower with the rain shower heads. Beds so comfy you thought you died and went to heaven.2. My husband had called the hotel and asked to have a rose in the room for me for my birtday. They told him that is part of our service, and we will be happy to do that at no cost to you. So a rose was waiting for me with a beautiful note from the wonderful hubby telling me to have the time of my life.3. That evening, the staff brought up a small cupcake size birthday cake for me with Happy Birthday written on the plate. Very thoughtful.4. Hotel was beautiful, unbelievable clean, beach was wonderful. They were constantly cleaning.I honestly cannot say one bad thing about the hotel. I thought it was the best hotel I had ever been in. Food was good (expensive - but you expect that). We for the most part just vegged on the beach. Weather was fantastic, around 85-87 each day, just a couple little sprinkles once or twice. I would recommend this resort to anyone.

<Author>jkloni
<Content>Enjoyed our stay at the Caribe Hilton Stayed one night post cruise. Main building 3rd floor. Room 318. I thought the room was just fine. Not a great view because we overlooked the roof of the main reservation area, but we were here only one night. The bed was extremely comfortable, the shower had plenty of hot water and water pressure. I did not have any type of smell in my room. The hallway smelled a tad musty, but it has to be because of all the moisture being right on the water.The pool, swim up bar and view of the ocean are just incredible.The pool area was not as clean as I would have expected from a Hilton property, but not disgusting. I don't know why people think it's ok to come from the beach into the pool to wash their feet. We smelled no odors while outside by the pool. (We had read and heard of this before. In fact, my husband was here last year and there was a very bad smell at that time out by the pool.We had drinks and ate burgers and appetizers at the swim up bar. the 8oz bacon cheeseburger with fries for $11 was very good. I thought $7 for a Corona and $3 for fountain cola was a bit pricey. We did not eat at the hotel. We went to Haceinda Don Jose for some great Mexican/Puerto Rican food instead.I liked the hotel enough that I would stay here again.Our main building room was fine, but my understanding is the Villa rooms are much nicer. We met a couple who were 1/2 thru a 2 week vacation that were initially in the Villa section but switched to the main building to be closer to everything. She said it took 15 minutes to walk from their Villa room to the main area of the hotel.

<Author>SineadG
<Content>Very nice experience Just back from a stay in the Caribe Hilton, Stayed one night before a cruise and two nights after. On arrival it looked fantastic. Very inpressive. The reception area is huge and there is a fabulous view out to the sea. We booked a Dble Dble Deluxe ocean view room as there was 3 of us. We got our ocean view on both check ins, in different parts of the hotel, both rooms were more or less the same, I did expect better for a Hilton the walls looked as if the paper was peeling off in some areas and the carpet did look old, the bathroom was lovely and clean and the beds were very comfy. We were just a little dissapointed with the rooms, but for the amt of time you spend in your room... the gounds well made up for it. Pools and beach absolutely beautiful, looks exactly like the picture on their web site. We ate in Mortons Steakhouse which is on the premises, the meal was delicious. The steaks are hugh, well worth trying, but a little expensive. The price list is outside so you know what to expect before you go in. The staff were all lovely from reception to bell boys to pool tenders. No complaints there. Overall we had a great time in the Caribe Hilton.

<Author>PacificHeights7
<Content>Fantastic Private Beach and Grounds, Bad Food, Fair Rooms We stayed at the Caribe Hilton for 3-nights in February of this year prior to our cruise of the Panama Canal. Puerto Rico is not one of my favorite Caribbean destinations. At best, the locals tolerate the tourists. But, the Caribe Hilton is a very nice property. It has a beautiful little private beach, a scenic promenade that runs right next to the ocean, a nice pool area, a good gym, and good tennis courts with pros on staff for lessons. I took a tennis lesson while I was there. The pro was American, friendly, helpful, and a good tennis player.The property offers hotel rooms and villas. We had a hotel room. The room was okay, but there was evidence of deferred maintenance everywhere. There was a musky smell in the room. There are GIANT signs in the hallways asking the maids not to scream and talk loudly.The restaurants were very disappointing. We did not have one good meal there. The service was not good either. We took advantage of the little convenience store right across the street. We walked to El Morro and Old Town. You walk out of the property and turn right. The views of the ocean were magnificent. There were homeless people sleeping in old cars across the street. Old Town is very run down and in need of much repair. Half of the shops are empty. There is a new casino in Old Town that caters to the cruise ship crowd.In summery, the grounds of the Caribe Hilton are fantastic. They are private and that is very important in crime-ridden Puerto Rico. The rooms and service were both fair, and the food is not good. If I were ever to go back to Puerto Rico, I think I would search for a resort away from town and stay away from the ultra sleezy Condado area.  
<Date>Oct 29, 2006

<Author>bmfree
<Content>Some good, some bad My hubbie and I spent a few days prior to a work trip at the Caribe Hilton in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The location was great, not too far from Old San Juan and not to far from the new upscale developments either. Hubbie is a Hilton Honors Member so we were upgraded to a better than average room in the tower that had recently been upgraded. Upon first site the room seemed pretty nice but when you looked closer the wall paper was rotten and there was mold growing on the walls. All that had been updated apparently was the furnishings. The bath room was really nice, but it to had mold that was trying to peel off the fresh coat of paint. The service was really nice and the beach was decent. Overall it was a pretty good experience but not a top property.

<Author>Californium
<Content>had a great time! Let me tell you that my wife and I are from San Francisco, CA and this was our first time to Puerto Rico. Being the control freak that I am I researched multiple web sites reading all the reviews on Puerto Rico Hotels, ranging from 3 star to the highest priced hotels. Interestingly, I found no hotel that had a perfect score- there's always going to be some that have a problem with something. We were constrained to being close to the cruise ship, so I focused on the San Juan area. I saw lots of complaints about the Caribe, but enough good reviews to take a chance- that balanced with some of the photos people posted and the going prices at the time made it the optimal value/price ratio.We did opt for the ocean view and we did have a wonderful view of the bay. However, you could see the rooftop of the 1st floor structure and it had some noisy a/c equipment. We were on the upper level so it wasn't so bad and you couldn't hear it at all if the window was closed. The room did smell a bit moldy when we first came in - like the a/c filter hadn't been cleaned in a long time. But it went away after keeping it on for awhile and opening the window. The room was otherwise nice and clean, and the mattresses extremely comfortable- slept VERY well.But you shouldn't stay in your room- the Caribe has some wonderful facilities. The pool area is fantastic, with multiple levels. There is a pool bar that is interesting, but the drinks were so-so and a bit overpriced. The Caribe also has their own private bay and beach which is fantastic. My favorite part was all the hammocks under the palm trees- I took a nap there. That was heaven. Also a nice promenade that is right on the ocean.For eating, we tried the Spanish restaurant on the premises. I thought the food was quite good, but don't order cocktails- opt instead for a good Spanish wine as they don't do cocktails very well. The breakfast buffet is also very good and I liked the exotic fruit juices they had. Eat outside on the patio and watch the geckos go by- inside was a bit too cold for us. I wish we had tried the other restaurants, but ended up eating at Ramiros, which was highly rated but we found disappointing (except for the wine). Seems like a lot of people have problems with the service. We had none. In fact, I found the staff was very helpful and courteous and always available to answer questions. We also used the on-site tour shop to go to the rain forest. It was well run and we had a good time. However, we were at the Caribe in August which is off season. My feeling is that when the East Coast crowd shows up it takes on a different character. I can see if that place is packed with families how it could take on a more stressful atmosphere. I will stay here again if I come back to Puerto Rico.  
<Date>Sep 24, 2006

<Author>PKGii
<Content>Money Was Stolen and Management Did Not Care While staying at the hotel money was stolen from wallets hidden in drawers, and pockets of clothing. The management was very patronizing, and basically said that since the money wasn't in the safe they weren't responsible. The Security Dept. did a check and found that two employees had entered the room during the time we were gone but we were informed that since they did not know which employee may have taken the money and since we had left it unattended there was nothing they could do. They would just watch the employees in the future. It is important to note that a limited amount of money was taken from two wallets - leaving us to believe that the employees take smaller amounts so hotel guests won't notice the missing funds. The only reason we noticed is because one of the wallets was dropped on the floor. Don't go to this hotel - it is not safe!

<Author>UnnamedTraveler
<Content>Our room was robbed! My friend and I were celebrating our 50th birthdays, and stayed at the Caribe prior to our cruise. We went down to the pool for two hours and when we returned, found one of our wallets on the floor. Upon investigation, we discovered that we were robbed of approximately $300 in cash--from my friend's wallet hidden in a phone book in a table, my wallet in my purse, my pants pocket, and the small change and bills we had lying on the table.Hotel security conducted an investigation, including a door key computer printout, and said they would send the results. We had to BEG the manager to come up and give us new room keys and told him we did not want anyone to enter our room for the remainder of our stay. After waiting almost two months to hear from anyone at the hotel, I finally wrote to hilton and my letter was forwarded to the hotel. I received a letter from the assistant manager of security basically telling me too bad, so sad, we're not responsible. Oh, and that their employees are all monitored and have a security background check. Oh, and if I want to come back, they'll give me a room upgrade or a free dinner. A free dinner would have been nice after the theft occurred, but nothing was offered at the time.Because a couple of people entered our room while we were at the pool, they cannot pinpoint the thief, and therefore, no one is held accountable.So, if you don't mind an employee rummaging through your clothes and taking what they please, by all means stay at this hotel.I am a diamond member of Hilton, and a travel agent, and this is the first time in over 30 years of travel that my room has been robbed. My theory is that they are taking a little bit from each room and the guests aren't noticing. We only knew because they dropped one of the wallets on the floor. Lesson learned -- if this happens again, I will call the local police immediately.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2006

<Author>yoshiposhi_pie
<Content>Overpriced with Sub-Par Service My husband and I booked the Caribe Hilton for our destination wedding and while the catering department and our wedding planner did an excellent job with the actual wedding ceremony and reception, our stay and the stay of our guests at the hotel was not as pleasant. Indeed, many of us were surprisingly disappointed that a hotel bearing the Hilton name was such a let down. It was only after our stay did we learn that Hilton does not operate all of its hotels and some, including the Caribe Hilton, are run by other entities who are permitted to use the Hilton name. First, with respect to the quality of the rooms, you would expect more for what you are paying to stay here. A lot of the rooms were damp, with the sheets and walls feeling wet. There was also an odor- probably related to the dampness. Another issue was with the indifferent hotel staff, from the front desk to management. We had an incident with one of our guests' ring being stolen from their room, and after getting the runaraound, we were left with an uncooperative security personnel whose attitude was pretty much oh well- too bad. One of the biggest peeves was at check out. If you choose to stay here, be sure to get in writing what you will be charged up front. We never had the situation before our stay here where, on top of our regular room rate, there was such a siginifcant amount of additional daily fees tacked on on top of the regular taxes and fees you would normally expect. for example, the Caribe Hilton tacks on a hefty fee for transporting luggage to your room, EVEN IF YOU CARRIED YOUR OWN BAGS TO YOUR ROOM. They also charge a daily cleaning fee, a daily resort fee, and automatically add a donation to a charity you never heard of. Going over the final bill was quite a frustrating experience realizing that after having tipped all the hotel staff for their various services throughout the stay, we were being charged on top of that for their services which any normal person would assume is included in the rate (i.e. maid service, a resort fee for hanging out at the pool, having your bags brought up). We will never stay here again, and would NEVER recommend this place to anybody. We have stayed at luxury resorts and budget inns, and the Caribe Hilton is by far the worst experience we have ever had out of all the places we have stayed at. Never again.  
<Date>Sep 8, 2006

<Author>Mauibreeze
<Content>Had a great time My husband and I stayed at the Caribe Hilton August 23 ?August 28 and we had a wonderful experience from the time we stepped out of the cab until we left. We were immediately greeted by the bellman and the front desk staff was courteous and helpful. We were upgraded to a Lagoon Villa room. The room had a small balcony (no room for chairs) with a nice view of the lagoon and the ocean. It was brand new, clean, had a comfortable bed and very nice bathroom. On Saturday morning there was noise from the air traffic at the little airport nearby-but it wasn bad. It was a little bit of a walk to get to from the main hotel, but we didn mind. The pool and hot tub near the Lagoon Villas and was a great alternative for when we didn feel like walking to the main pool. This pool was quiet and we usually had it to ourselves. The Villas also had their own front desk which we used to check-out, call cabs, ask questions etc. Every hotel staff person we came in contact with was friendly and courteous-even passing in the halls people would say hello and good morning. We ate lunch at the pool grill, breakfast at Palmera and had drinks at the lobby bar  pool bar. The food prices were expensive-but it is expected-any hotel has expensive restaurants. The lobby bar didn seem to have enough help some nights to wait the tables, so we usually ended up ordering directly at the bar. The drinks were good and fairly priced.The main pool was very nice. It was crowded on Sunday, along with the lagoon. Most days we opted to sit in chairs that were on the ocean (on the sidewalk leading to the fish pier). The fish pier was great; it was neat to be able to see so many fish so close without snorkeling. We were not overcharged for anything. The resort fee of $20 was a little annoying-but since we had such a great experience and paid 1% sales tax the whole time we were in PR, I got over it. The hotel is in a great location, we walked to Old San Juan one day, took the bus most other days. We also walked over to Condado a number of times. Being New Yorker's - we felt the cabs were expensive so we only took them at night.I was nervous because I had read the negative reviews on this site before we left. We had no problems whatsoever. We would recommend staying here and would stay again in the future.  
<Date>Aug 30, 2006

<Content>Not so good. I have to agree with most posters here that the rooms and service at Caribe Hilton are very lacking. I was here on business staying at the Caribe for a second time. It was no better than the first go around. The rooms are really bad. I don't know how else to say it. My boss made the reservations and she is a Diamond Member. Trouble with the room key - I will be right back. It's midnight. She comes back and I just asked her straight out - someone was in that room, right? Yup. Had to move you to another floor. The rooms are just old. Everything needs updating. The bathrooms are very old. Breakfast - check it out. The fruit on the breakfast bar had mold on it. We usually just stick to the executive lounge, but we were meeting people that morning and we all went downstairs. Just okay.Location is great for me, but I just cannot abide by these rooms. Come on Hilton - $239 plus that resort fee in low season and you can't get some money to update the rooms?I think I will go back to the Ritz where our corporate rate is and put up with their bad service. At least the rooms are better.

<Author>jayded1
<Content>Not bad.... I recently spent 6 nights at the Caribe while attending a conference. Check in was at about 5pm and took a total of 3 minutes, however the bellstaff were not eager so I walked my own bags to my room. I was in the villas on the second floor, the room was of fair size with a full kitchen and great balcony. The room was fresh and recently renovated, while there were plates, sliverware and glasses no cooking utensils or pans /pots were to be found (or soap for the dishwasher)! All in all the room was great.The Caribe has a few chioces for dining and I tried most of them, Mortons Steakhouse ($$$$) was by far the best with a close second being the Palmeras ($$) they have different nightly buffets and the roasting night was great (makes me think I should have tried the Puerto Rican night as well). During the afternoons or all day on the weekend the main pool bar is a buzz of people but I was very impressed with the bar staff as even as they were outnumbered 100 to 1 the levels of service were superb and as a man I didn't have on a two piece bikini but after brief wait the bartender came over introduced himself and asked my name then made the best pina colada EVER for me twice! The hotel needs to have this guy train all their staff.The beach and pool area are great, to get a hammock during prime time you need to move fast but the best time I had was after dinner about 10:30PM and walking out the pier thingy past the hammocks and looking at the fish that are attracted to the bring lights...they were huge and I was wishing for my speargun but alas its a no fishing or swimming zone just feeding which the hotel does daily as an attraction.Overall I would happily return to the Caribe Hilton.

<Author>elastopathy
<Content>Surely you can find somewhere else to stay I stayed in an executive-level room in the newer tower and the room itself was not bad and had a nice view. The executive level lounge had a good seleciton of snacks and drinks throughout the day. The grounds itself are generally pretty and include a tropical garden with a pond with swans, a private beach, two pools, and several restaurants and shops. So much for the good parts.Unfortunately, there were negative aspects that significantly cut into enjoying a vacation here, and they all revolve around terrible service and overcharging. For these reasons, I would advise you to stay elsewhere.We requested a nonsmoking room with two beds and confirmed it twice. Instead, we received a room that smelled of stale smoke, was on a floor with no non-smoking signs, and had just a single (king-size) bed. I was hesitant to request a room change, because from my experience, there can be a punative component and the replacement room is quite often worse.The service is poor. The valets and bellmen don't come out to greet you when you drive up, and the valet service takes a very long time to retrieve your car. The concierge is curt and answers most questions with a pre-printed sheet of paper. The driving directions that they handed out actually had an error. The paper handed to me a checkin listed the incorrect location for the breakfast area and executive lounge.Internet service is $15/day, but even if you want to pay, it doesn't work. The number to call for help connects to a support person in Warsaw, Poland (really).The phone in our room stopped working one day.Our room key cards expired and had to be reprogrammed at least once and sometimes twice per day.The final insult is the over-charging. In addition to a 9% tax, be prepared to find a 10% resort fee and a $1/day donation to an orphanage on your bill. They told me the resort fee was required by Puerto Rico law (yeah, right) and they would remove the orphanage donation but their computer was not working and told me to call back when I returned home.  
<Date>Aug 13, 2006

<Author>jms238
<Content>Great place to stay This is an excellent hotel. The open-air lobby is very nice. Our room (in the main building) was very large and had a beautiful view of the ocean and the pool. The renovation of the hotel has made the whole property very nice.The pool was nice and the hammocks were relaxing. The grounds are very nice.For those who are disillusioned with the price of extras, welcome to resort hotels! You have to know that going in.The Caribe Hilton is a nice jumping off point for Condado or Old San Juan. Public transportation is close and cheap for those who don't want to take a cab, or you can walk if you're up to it.If there are cons, it is that the room has practically no electrical outlets and that the check-in process was the longest I have ever seen.However, don't hesitate to stay here. It's worth the money.

<Author>kennyw12345
<Content>perfect relaxation spot... despite the reviews I booked the Caribe Hilton on Hotwire[--] for 3 nights before a cruise and booked on Priceline[--] for 1 night after the cruise. After reading all the reviews on tripadvisor I was a bit scared to say the least. I realized that I needed a new tower room. Well, my new wife and I showed up there and were not given a tower room. I was not the least bit disappointed. We had a room on the 7th floor of the main building and had a great view! The room and the view were absoulutely magnificant! Everyone was friendly. It was a nice walk to Condado to eat and even Old San Juan was not a bad walk.I cant figure out why there are so many bad reviews of this hotel. The pool was great too. Like I said, we did not have a new tower room, and we were still completely satisified with a main building room.By the way, it seems that most people paid $275 per night and up. We still would have been satisfied if we had paid that, but we booked on hotwire for $89/night and on Priceline for $77/night!! Even if we had not gotten this great rate we would still go back and pay $275/night.

<Author>youthtrips
<Content>Not so great We recently took a group of 30 people to Puerto Rico and stayed at the Hilton Caribe for our last two nights on the island. The booking process went smoothly, but the morning of check in is when the bad customer service began. From the moment I called to confirm our check- in, to the moment we left, none of our group had good reports for their workers. Most were just unhelpful and some were just snide. I did have a run in with a pleasant clerk,one helpful valet guy, and the consierge that was more than willing to help me, but as for the rest of the time we felt as if they were doing us a favor by letting us stay there. I would hope that when you pay any amount of money for a service, you would be treated like you are paying for a service instead of feeling like an unwanted house guest that's in for the weekend. The grounds of the hotel were beautiful and very convenient. The only comment on the food is to be prepared to spend more than you bargained for because EVERYTHING is an extra cost. Even the complementary water that most hotels (even cheap ones) give to you in the room had a hidden cost of $7.00. I personally don't like to feel as though I'm being tricked into spending my money; if I'm prepared or I feel as though I'm getting something for my money then I have no problem handing it over. All in all I'd rather pay a lot more money for a hotel that pretends to like their guests then save a couple dollars.  
<Date>Jul 21, 2006

<Author>arounddeworld
<Content>Nice Hotel Just got back from a one week vacation in P.R. We stayed at the Caribe Hilton for 2 nights. Our experience upon arrival echoed some of the previous reviews regarding the check-in process. We were given a room in the executive tower, only to find a large hole in the ceiling, above the shower. After complaining (nicely) we were given an upgrade to the villas. Unfortunately we encountered many who were dissatisfied with their rooms. Our room was clean with a great view. The hotel was relatively close to the Condado area (15-20min walk) although there was a mini-mart across the street. We were told the walk to OSJ was only 15 minutes, in reality it was more like 50min-1 hour and we are all in great shape. The gym had decent equipment and the restaurant food was good. Overall we (2 adults-2 teens) felt it was a nice property and would stay again.

<Author>trvlfreek
<Content>Beautiful resort, excellent service, bad rooms!! This is a belated posting from our post-cruise stay at the Caribe Hilton from Jan 1st - Jan 3rd this year! I must say I did not wanna get off the ship but once we arrived at the resort - I had no regrets. It was just beautiful and as you walk to the ocean after check-in, you get a sense of the vast lobby. Since we arrived around 11, we were told our room won't be ready till 2:30. So, we decided to have lunch by the pool and just relax and take it all in! The beach is small but clean. We got a room on the 9th floor in the tower next to the main resort. The view wasn't WOW but it was still very nice. It had a rain shower and a very well done bathroom. My ONLY complaint was the mold and a strong smell throughout the room. We opened up the doors as soon as we walked in hoping it will go away in a few hours. But it didn't and I got a weird rash/itch each time I got into the bed. Next morning, I complained to the housekeeping and within minutes the manager was over and promised to take care of it. She changed the bedding, quilt, and all the sheets and even left me a note explaining all that was done to take care of the problem while we were out. We came back around 7:30pm and she immediately called to check if we still had the same problem. That was very nice of her and I thanked her for her service. It felt fine until an hour to two when I got the same itch as I got ready for bed. My husband opened one of the cabinets - and there it was - A Nasty cabinet FULL of mold. It was too disgusting to even look at it. I am not sure if it was just our room or what, but I couldn't stop itching the two night we spent here. This was our first resort experience in the Caribbean and I would go back any day. The bus stop is very close by and will take you to Old San Juan for a couple of dollars in 15-20 minutes - so worth it! The only place to eat nearby is a Subway so definitely pack up water bottles and snacks when out shopping in any grocery store. Overall, it was a great place to be and worth every penny and more for $95.00 on priceline!!!!!!!!!!  
<Date>Jul 13, 2006

<Author>Jaie
<Content>Beautiful, Relaxing and Enjoyable!! Wow! We booked this hotel as part of our travel package through our travel agent. When reading some of the reviews here (before traveling) I was VERY worried! However, the Caribe Hilton rooms, staff, facilities and offerings were all very accommodating for us! We arrived in SJ early (10 a.m.). We were allowed to register at the front desk, change our clothes in changing rooms, explore the hotel grounds, and have a very delicious lunch. When we checked back our room was ready. I must admit I was disappointed that our OceanVIEW room was not oceanFRONT!! It's hard to describe but from our balcony we could see the ocean but just below our balcony was the ROOF of a smaller hotel building so we had to try to block out that cement eyesore and look way over it to see the beach. I returned to the front desk to ask for a room with a better view and was told NONE of the rooms is truly oceanFRONT and that they were full and therefore unable to move us to another room. I was not happy about that but must admit the rest of the stay (ignoring the obstructed view) was great! For the reviewer who said they didn't change the towels... there was some notice that stated in an effort to conserve energy the hotel gives the guests the option to have their towels changed daily or not. If you wanted them changed you were to take the used towels off the racks. If I had not read that bit of info I too would have been upset to return to the room  to the same old towels! But a quick call to housekeeping would have resolved that. We enjoyed the pool, the beach, the restaurants, the fitness room, AND had delicious pizza from ROOM Service (can u believe that?) We also took advantage of the tours available in the lobby ~ opting for a day at the rainforest. Our travel agent put together a pretty comprehensive package so we weren't hit with any surpise fees or taxes... Oh! and by the way, we took taxis from the hotel to Old San Juan a couple of times including the day we were leaving. So, once again, after checking out the bellhops held our luggage while we ran into Old SJ for a museum tour and some final shopping. All-in-all, the Caribe Hilton was beautiful and fun and the staff was wonderful!!  
<Date>Jul 9, 2006

<Content>Over rated The hotel has the best frozen drinks but then goes down hill from there.The carpets in the hallways are stained with large bleach spots.The walls in the rooms have flaking paint and water stains. The sheets are stained.The pool is open for local kids to come and go as they please, which gives little room for the hotel guest to use the pool. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Avoid This Hotel!! Originally I had planned to stay at the Ritz, but a friend of mine that lives in San Juan recommended the HiltonIG MISTAKE. I was going there with my wife for our 5 year wedding anniversary. My friend recommended that we stay in the Villas, but request a room on the ocean side as a new building was being built on the other side and the construction started at 4:30 a.m. I called and made the reservation 2 weeks in advance of our stay and requested the Ocean side. The day before our arrival, I sent an email to confirm. I received an email back that yes, we would receive a room, high up and on the ocean side. Also stated that we could have an early check in. We arrived at around 1:00 p.m. I was told that our high-up, ocean view room wasn available, but that it would be ready within 1 hour. We had taken the red eye flight from Phoenix on Jet Blue and had been up for a total of 18 hours straight.Knowing that we were going to get a great room, I didn have a problem waiting the 1 hour, so we had lunch at the hotel. At 2:30 pm I was told another 30 minutes, so we simply hung out in the lobby. At 3, told another 30 minutes. This went on for about another hour. At 4 pm we decided to take a taxi around the island. At 6 pm we came back and were given our room keys ?the room was on the 1st floor, with a view of a wall, over on the construction side. I went to complain and was told that they would move us to another room. I had also asked for a room with a kitchen ?was told that the new room had one. The new room we were given was also on the construction side and had no kitchen. I was told that the following day that they would move us to a better location. The room we were given was dirty and the curtains didn close all the way, so in the morning, it was very hard to sleep with the loud construction noise and the sunlight coming into the room. The next day, I was told that they didn have another room and that we would be stuck in this room. The room that they claimed had a kitchen, only had a mini refrigerator and a coffee maker ?I don call this a kitchen. Our room keys stopped working 3 separate times and each time, the rude staff made us feel that it was our fault or that we were too stupid to know how to unlock the door. Funny thing is that from checking reviews online, others had the same experience. The pool was extremely dirty and hotel staff was pretty much all rude. Having a problem with paying around $300 per night for such a dump, we tried to check out. However we were told that since we didn give 24 hours notice, we would have to pay another $200. I decided to just stick it out a few more nights ?things went downhill even more from here ?no clean towels, more rude service, AC stopped working ?finally on the last night of our stay in San Juan, we checked out and went to the Embassy Suites ?what a difference and the rooms here were only $175 per night ?people were extremely friendly. One last comment about the Hilton ?be careful of all the extra charges. When I booked over the phone, I was told that the room rate was $285 per night and 9% tax. However when checking out, I see that they also added a 10% resort fee. When I asked what this was for, I was told that it was for the upkeep of the pool, as well as for housekeeping and the bellboy service. This was always part of the hotel fee in the past. This hotel also charges $15 per day for internet access and around $8 for the 1st minute to call the States. They also force you to make a donation to omeless children?for each day that you stay ?automatically appears on your bill at the time of check out. AVOID THIS PLACE!  
<Date>Jul 3, 2006

<Author>meital
<Content>Our favorite hotel My wife and I have traveled extensively to Europe, Africa, Asia, the South Pacific, Mexico and the Caribbean. I can state unequivocably that the Caribe Hilton in San Juan is far and away our favorite. Unlike the other San Juan hotels it has a lovely private beach. The general manager makes enormous effort to upgrade the hotel and its amenities. But the secret of the Caribe Hilton's success is its highly intelligent and motivated staff. This is true of each and every chambermaid right up to the staff and supervision at the front desk, the corporate and executive lounges. I make this statement based upon many visits to this hotel (4X a year) and innumerable interactions with the staff.Frequent travelers are aware that misunderstandings and mistakes can happen in the best of hotels.I cannot account for another reviewer's alleged negative experience with Enitza, in the executive lounge, but our experience with her has been invariably positive. She is a very sweet and helpful girl who did not deserve the comment made by that other reviewer.

<Author>yoshapman
<Content>Loved the Caribe Hilton My wife and I stayed at the Caribe Hilton in May-June 2005 for 7 nights, and it was amazing. It was our belated honeymoon, so we wanted everything to be perfect. I had luckilly signed up for a promotion a month before i went where I became a Hilton Gold member. We payed in advance on expedia for $100 a night (I dont understand why it is now $170 a night, but thats just me). The first thing I did when we got there was tell them it was our honeymoon and that I was a goldmember, and they upgraded us to an amazing oceanview room with a balcony. The view of the ocean was amazing. The room was well kept, with everything being refilled nightly. They also gave us a complimentary bottle of champagne and chocolate strawberries (though I did have to remind them twice before they brought it up, but hey free is free). We frequented the Starbucks a lot, didnt eat a any of the other restaurants, but they looked nice. The bar was ok, although I ordered the same drink each night and it somehow came out differently each time, sometimes good and sometimes bad. The pools were amazing, overlooking the ocean. They had a gameroom which was small but nice to have. The location was ok - we actually walked to Old San Juan, took about 25 minutes each way, on the way back we tried to get a cab but none passed, and it was quite hot. It was also a 15 minute walk to the Wyndham hotel with a casino, and the birdge which we needed to walk over was rickity. However, lal in all the hotel was really nice and it is the sole reason we are going to another Hilton for our vacation this year in Curacao - also, we got that resort for $70 a night plus tax so cant beat the price.  
<Date>Jun 20, 2006

<Author>mh_ct
<Content>Very pleased with our stay at Caribe Hilton My parents, sister and I stayed at the Caribe Hilton for a week in May and were very pleased overall. Noteworthy positives (in no particular order) based on our experience :(1) Great location - very close to Escambron (one of the 4 Blue flag beaches in PR)(2) Close to Old San Juan (easily accessible by cabs/buses)(3) Small but clean private beach (which is a huge bonus if you're feeling too lazy to venture out to one of the public beaches) with several hammocks and plenty of beach chairs(4) Helpful and courteous hotel staff (5) Knowledgeable conceirge (gave us great direction to the sights in and around San Juan)(6) The hotel offers day trips/tours that originate at the hotel which are a great option for folks that dont drive.Some disadvantages:(1) The hotel does offer seven or more dining options, but we found it to be over priced (2) But if you dont want to eat at the hotel, you dont have too many options near the hotel (other than a Subway 5 mins away from the hotel enterance); but Old San Juan offers seveal options (for different budgets) and I would recommend eating before you get back to your Hotel given the lack of choices around the hotel.  
<Date>Jun 15, 2006

<Author>Lippylulu
<Content>LOVED the Caribe Hilton and the Executive Lounge 4 1/2 stars I just returned from 3 nights at the Caribe HIlton where I traveled alone for business. I LOVED THIS HOTEL! When I checked in I told them I was a woman alone and asked for a room in a busy area of the hotel. They upgraded me to the executive level in the main building. I was able to go from my conference to my room quickly and always felt safe, and the executive lounge is fantastic! They have a free continental breakfast with more than just donuts (toast, muffins, cereal, fruit, yogurt). They have free drinks and hordeovers from 5:30-8 pm and mini desserts and cordials at night. Troughout the day there is free soda, water, coffee, fruit and little ham sandwiches which I ate for lunch rather than spend $20 for lunch at one of the restaurants. It allowed me to splurge on some really great dinners---twice at Madrid, the spanish restraunt, and once at Morton's, the upscale and pricey steakhouse. The Executive Lounge also had a computer with free high speed internet for checking email, printing boarding passes, etc. as well as 2 wide screen TV's and daily newspapers including the NY Times. Does it get much better than that?I heard the tower building rooms were better than the main building, but I was thrilled to be in the main building. The location is closer to the beach and pool, and my room was one of the largest and most comfortable I have been in. Although it did not have a balcony, it did have a HUGE picture window with an oceanfront view. From what I could tell the balconies on other rooms were very small so this was fine for me. I moved the comfy arm chair and ottoman right next to that window and felt like I was sitting above the sea. The a/c worked well and my room was always cleaned early, with turn down service too! The linens were upscale and the room was very attractive with a LARGE closet, marble bathrom, etc. When I checked in there was a flickering, buzzing lightbulb in the bathroom. One phone call and it was fixed. The bathroom had Crabtree and Eveyln toiletries. Nice!The pool area at this hotel is lovely, though it seemed a bit crowded when the hotel filled up on the weekend. I never had trouble finding a lounge chair, quiet area or shady spot. The beach is small. The water is calm, clear and clean with no rocks or yucky seeweed areas, but it is not the crystal blue water I love in the Caribbean. Again, plenty of lounge chairs and umbrellas. The garden area is gorgeous and a great place to relax in the shade, read a book, etc with lovely flowers and even a couple of swans along the lagoon.I visited the SPA for a refelxology massage and must say this was a big disasppointment. The SPA itself is lovely, but they must have assigned me a beginner. Either she knew nothing about reflexology or she was really bad at it. I should have complained on the spot but I didn't.My final criticism is that the banana daiqeries at the pool bar were really lousy. I was surprised they didnt use real bananas but instead just a mix. Blech. For such a nice hotel they should really improve this.This hotel caters to families and business travelers. I would not go there for my honeymoon, but next time I go for business I will bring my family (if it was just vacation I might pick a place with a more expansive, white sand blue water beach). It would have been nice if there were some more moderately priced dining options, but I guess thats good motivation to leave the hotel. BTW, there is a Starbucks in the lobby which was great for a less expensive dessert.I have travelled extensively in the Caribbean but this was my first trip to PR. This is a top notch hotel. The restaurants were SUPERB! I gave it 5 stars though really it deserves 4 1/2. Trip Advisor should have a category for VERY good instead of just above average.  
<Date>Jun 12, 2006

<Author>Muriel12
<Content>Nice property, dated room, poor customer service I stayed at the Caribe for four nights in March. The property is nice, with its own beach area, but be prepared to rely on taxis or rental car if you're interested in doing much outside of the resort property.The beach area is small but nice. They have a nice lagoon-like area for tranquil swimming. Snorkling equipment is available--for a charge, but it's worth it. Saw plenty of beautiful ocean life. I had a nice breakfast in the dining room. Very well-presented buffet with a variety of options for all tastes. I was very disappointed in the room for the price we paid ($199 per night). After being there for two nights, I chatted with a friend who was also staying there and discovered that there are very different room types in different areas of the resort. She too was paying $199 but had a VERY different room. Mine was dark and outdated with worn furnishings and a bathroom in need of renovation. Hers was bright, airy and newly renovated. Our bed was short-sheeted. One hour into sleep on the first night, I awoke to find that the bottom sheet had creeped up under my knees. I called the front desk to complain and they assured me that the matter would be resolved the next day. This happened EVERY day, despite my repeated calls. Does the hotel not have adequate-sized sheets?????I interacted with staff members at the reception desk three times and with the concierge once. All of the staff were incredibly rude.The final annoyance occurred during check-out. I reviewed my bill and saw that I had been charged a mandatory fee that went to housekeeping and bellhop staff. Upon check-in, not a single bellhop had offered to assist with luggage (even though plenty of guys were standing around). And after the battle over the sheets, I was determined not to pay a penny for housekeeping service. I was able to get the charge removed, but did not receive so much as an apology for the negligent service.

<Author>essman
<Content>Beware of fraudulent charges I'm a HHonors Gold, which entitles members to late check out, when available, according to HHonors policy. I stayed in early Jan. 06, asked for late check-out, was told by Enitza in the Exec. Lounge (who was rude) that it wasn't available, and then told it was available for $75. I was ripping and declined to pay them $75 to stay until 2:00 p.m. Enitza called me in my room, said they had a parlor room available for 2 hours, never mentioned the $75 again, so I accepted. When I got my card statement, the total bill for the stay was higher than I expected. I had to contact the hotel several times and in Feb. I got a copy of my statement, which included the $75 charge PLUS other charges that I had not made. I had saved my reservation with the rate, which also quoted a $20 resort fee. The bill charged $25---$5 bucks, big deal. Had they not tried to rip me off, I would have let it slide. BUT, since it was next to impossible to contact anyone there and since the staff here is totally unresponsive, I had to dispute the charge with VISA. Bottom line, the charges were reversed and 2 weeks ago it was removed from my card. Not a bad property, but the customer service was obnoxious. If you like staying in a place where the staff is condescending and acts like they are doing you a serious favor by letting you stay, this is the place. Otherwise, Marriott is just down the street, in a better location, and with a better beach....and without the obnoxious attitude.

<Author>velvetflip
<Content>Great Week at the Caribe Hilton! My boyfriend and I just returned from a wonderful week at the Caribe Hilton. We had a beautiful king deluxe room in the Hilton Honors Tower. Our room had a balcony providing amazing sea views. The bathroom was incredible - all granite, his  hers sinks, huge walk-in glass shower with sitting area and 2 shower heads.We stuffed ourselves at the breakfast buffet in Palmera's Restaurant every morning. The selection was great - fresh fruits, eggs, meats, cheeses, cereals, breads/pastries, juices and champagne, too! We had dinner at Morton's and Lemongrass. Morton's was good, what you would expect from any Morton's. Lemongrass was very quiet and intimate, but the menu was a little overdone. Still, it was a great option when we did not want to leave the hotel one night and is in a lovely setting in the hotel's garden. We enjoyed room service a couple of times for sandwiches and the food was also excellent. However, the hotel could speed up it's tray removal from the hall!The hotel's facilities are great. The private beach is clean with plenty of beach chairs and umbrellas available. The pools are clean and the swim up bar is a lot of fun! Oh, and don't forget to say hello to the parrots in the lobby, Pancho and Koko...they may say hello back to you!The hotel spa, Olas, is great. We had a couple's massage on our first day and it was a great start to a week of relaxation. We really liked the hotel's location - away from the busy Isla Verde strip. It was a $20.00 cab ride from the airport, and only a $10.00 cab ride to Old San Juan. We wanted a week of complete relaxation and we got that and more at the Caribe Hilton!

<Author>Barracuda30
<Content>Great Place to Stay Positive: My wife and I just got back from a week there. We stayed 15-23 May, and the weather was great. They have a good pool with a swim-up bar as well as a private little beach. The room was clean and housekeeping service was like clockwork every day. The room air conditioning was great (freezing if you wanted it to be) and that was OK with me, because it was pretty hot outside. There's also a good bar/lounge located next to the lobby with some live entertainmment most nights. The rooms have a small refigerator and mini-bar, hair blowers, and iren/ironing board, although our room's iron was missing. Not a big deal, I called down for one and they brought it up right away. A plus with me was the hotel internet access in the rooms. Several clothing and other stores are located in the lobby/ground floor area. The main advantage to the Hilton is its central location near Old San Juan with its historical sites and museums, the Condado area on Ashford Avenue just across the Dos Hermanos Bridge, and the easy accessibility to Highway 26. Be prepared to take plenty of photos, bring plenty of SPF35 sun protector, and buy yourself a hat for protection from the sun. Anytime you're away from the beach or the pool, it's going to be very hot. We got a bargain through Hotels(-) at $161/day room rate. Lots of great food and drink, especially if you know where to go! I would definitely stay again. Don't gamble on anything less than a 4 or 5-star hotel. Anything less gets seedy and you get what you pay for. My second choice in that area would be the Condado Plaza Hotel and Casino just across the Dos Hermanos Bridge from the Hilton, or the Ritz Carlton.Negative: The only thing that really bugs me in Puerto Rico is that the hotels charge extra or separately for parking. You are a paying guest at the Caribe Hilton and yet they charge you $15 a day extra to park. The good thing about the Hilton is that they add it onto your room bill when you check out. At some others you pay as you go on a daily basis. It's just a pet peeve of mine that I think if you're a paying guest you shouldn't be charged for parking, but virtually all the hotels in San Juan do it. Somebody should complain to the tourism bureau or something.Tip: Parking is HORRIBLE in Old San Juan, so be prepared to park somewhere along Ponce de Leon Avenue (around La Casa de Espaa or the Taxation Building Hacienda), then walk straight into La Fortaleza Street in Old San Juan. Ponce de Leon Avenue turns into La Fortaleza Street from Plaza Colon (the square with a fountain and a tall statue of Christopher Columbus) onward.

<Author>CateW
<Content>Had a wonderful time .... My husband and I just returned from 5 nights at the Caribe Hilton in San Juan. Let's say I was more than a little nervous about this hotel because of the negative reviews. Our flight out of JFK arrived early and our room wasn't ready when we arrived. I have to say that I was a little disappointed in the changing rooms. They were small and not well appointed so I was a little wary... but when our room was ready we got an upgrade to an ocean view room on the 8th floor. The room was spacious and the view was very nice. The room was clean, although it could have used a face lift - new carpeting and bead spreads would have made a world of difference. We spent most of our time either at the pool or on the beach, both of which were just wonderful. There was never an issue getting chairs or towels and the weather was fabulous. Due to the dining options, (Mortons, Lemongrass, an Italian and Spanish restaurant there was really no reason to leave for us). The bar was lively and the entertainment was pretty good. Puerto Rico is perfect from us because of the direct flight options out of NYC and the weather always cooperates. It's also a big plus that they have a Starbucks right in the hotel which is a great quick breakfast option and the pool bar and restuarant and beach chair service made for a very relaxing trip. We will go back.

<Author>recenttraveler48
<Content>The Caribe was a nice week Yes, it was built in the 50's, but there's a real funky charm to the place, and much of it has been totally redone. The staff -every single peron-was helpful, polite and seemed to be having fun! The hotel is short cab ride from Old San Juan, and in our view, that was a good thing. The beach was excellent, as were the pools. We had a room in the tower with a great view and beautiful breeze. We were at a convention and the hotel handled it seamlessly. You can venture out for food--there are lots of places to eat just a short cab ride away. Very relaxing.

<Author>usckim01
<Content>Not as terrible as the reviews Our room was spacious and clean. I did notice some old wall areas that were not patched up properly, but nothing that hindered our stay. Concierge was very helpful and we didn't have much to complain about. I will say that we paid $90 per night on priceline and had we paid $200+ like some of the other guests, I might have been more particular about things. We didn't spend too much time at the hotel because we had lots of tours, but we were VERY grateful that we stumbled upon Lemongrass (one of the restaurants in the hotel) on our last night. I have eaten at nearly all the highest rated restaurants in NYC, plus many others spanning over 20 countries, and Lemongrass was probably up there as one of my favorite overall dining experiences. I've had higher quality food elsewhere, but when you combine the service, innovative menu, well-executed food, and chic but not overly pretentious ambience with decent prices (not cheap, but decent), it exceeded expectations. Even if you decide not to stay at the Hilton, you must try Lemongrass.  
<Date>May 17, 2006

<Author>mcderni
<Content>A little disappointing I just returned from the Caribe hilton, stayed from 5/12 - 5/15. I took my mother for the weekend as a mothers day gift. I have been a few places and I don't consider myself fussy but I have to say, I was disappointed in the whole Puerto rico experience considering how expensive everthing is over there. At first I requested a room in the main building based on a review I read here that these were the better rooms. That was not true these rooms were in desperate need of repair maybe even just a fresh coat of paint would have made it better. The bathroom I could barely turn around in and I'm only 140lbs and there was mildew in between the tiles. The second day I requested to be tranfered to a room in the executive tower because another guest told me that thes rooms were renovated. These rooms had larger bathrooms with marble walls and double sinks, but the wall in the room were again dirty. I mean writing on the walls dirty and paint peeling off. The room also smelled musty, I guess from the humidity but they should figure out how to get rid of that smell they are a large hotel. The grounds were nice. The pool was very crowded with a lot of kids running around. The restaurants, we only had breakfast in one it was ok. We mostly ate in Old San Juan. We had access to the executive lounge wher they offerd free continental breakfast which we also had one morning and that was ok also. Overall it was an ok trip, I had read the reviews by some people here and thought maybe they were just picky, but I guess not.

<Author>naturalogg
<Content>Liked the hotel; loved Lemongrass restaurant Like everyone else, I was nervous to select this hotel in light of some of the bad reviews shown by prior travelers. However, I reasoned that you couldn't beat the price for a Hilton (we paid $170/night for a standard room on the pre-paid plan, 5/11-5/14) and the location seemed to be ideal (halfway between Condado and Old San Juan - we determined true walkability when we got there).We arrived around 1:30, and I checked ahead of time to see how booked the hotel would be during our stay and it appeared to be not more than 50% occupied. Nonetheless, we were told we would have to wait two hours to check in, which was fine as we were more interetested in drinks than naps at that point anyway. Had a bite and a few drinks at the Atlantico pool bar. Service was friendly but slow, hamburgers were pretty poor and not necessarily beef (as evidenced by our upset stomachs later on), but drinks were tasty and welcomed. Prices very high for the quality on food, acceptable for drinks ($11 cheeseburger, $8 pina colada, $7.50 Corona). Finally checked in around 4pm to Garden Wing room 753. Room was spacious (even bathroom, contrary to other reviews) and the view was amazing (fort, ocean, other two wings). Evidence of a few leaks in the ceiling that were roughly patched up, but not terribly offensive.Dinner first night in Madrid-San Juan restaurant on the property. Great selection of wines, tapas, and true spanish entrees. Sat at the bar; Luis, the bartender, was very helpful in advising us which menu items to steer clear of (tortilla espanola is not fresh! not fresh at all!) and in picking out where to go and when from a tourist perspective. Slow service there as well but we were in no rush so it was fine. Food was very good and very reminiscent of northern and southern Spanish cuisines; prices were very reasonable (dinner was actually cheaper than lunch). Glass of house wine (very tasty) is $10.The next few days were delightfully lazy. There are several areas in which to sit around the water (big pool complex off of main building, smaller pool/jacuzzi area off of Garden Wing, small beach closer to the spa). Lunch from the health bar was tasty but expensive ($27 for two wraps and two cans of soda). No complaints about the pool (aside from your usual noisy families making their way through); comfy chairs and towels, ideal water temperature and generally spacious deck areas.Tried the walk to Old San Juan; probably should have brought a map as it was longer than we expected, and it takes you through some shady areas if you don't know the way very well. Cabs will take you there for $15 but you can (and SHOULD) negotiate with them, as they'll do it for as low as $7-$10 (it's a 7-minute ride). The tourism department has schedules of ridiculous fares for various rides (including airport to Hilton) but they're way out of line and, apparently, always negotiable. Old San Juan is quaint, pretty, and almost exactly what its name implies: an old spanish town, now teeming with jewelry and tourist shops in the daytime. At night, it's your typically metropolitan hot-spot, with its fair share of urban chic bars, nightclubs, and lounges. All reasonably priced, great atmosphere, and a lovely mix of locals and tourists.Condado is a shorter walk with a less thrilling atmosphere. More of a strip, with pockets of visitor-friendliness scattered about. Ajili Mojili was the recommended restaurant, and rightly so with its well-prepared truly Puerto Rican cuisine. We were underdressed, even for mid-day lunch, in shorts and t-shirts but service was nonetheless friendly and attentive.The most important aspect of my review is our final night's dinner at Lemongrass in the hotel. This is one of the greatest dining experiences I have ever had, home or abroad. Atmosphere, service, food, and overall ambience was absolutely amazing, and I'd never go back to Puerto Rico without going back to this restaurant. It was priced appropriately for the quality, and it was the perfect ending to our vacation. Can't stop raving, and won't attempt to disparage any aspect of it by detailing any other aspect...I'll just say it was really, really great. And I'm usually very picky about great restaurants.I've been going to Bermuda every year since I was 2 (I'm 23), and this was a new experience for me. It's not the classiest island, but it's not trying to be. It's more like a very spanish version of Miami, as my boyfriend aptly described it. It's clearly thick with tourism, construction, political dissention, and entertainment. I prefer Bermuda, but am glad to have seen Puerto Rico and will probably go back at least once in my lifetime. Next time, however, I might stay in another part of the country and do more of a nature sightseeing vacation as opposed to our RR vacation this time around.  
<Date>May 15, 2006

<Author>BluesTraveling
<Content>Very nice hotel, but nothing comes cheap Like a previous reviewer, I was also at this hotel for a large conference. Overall, I found the facilities, rooms, and staff to be excellent. The exercise room was nice, the pools were well-attended, and the views and access to the beach cannot be topped. The adjacent Spanish fort was a nice touch, too. The short pier was also a great place for some fish-watching. The room (in the Villas) was nice as well, particularly the large bathroom and the water view from the short private balcony. If you want a resort experience, you can find it here. My only complaint is the overall price. I got a good room rate for the conference, but I was amazed at what the steep room cost does not offer in the amenities department. Internet was available in the room but for $14.95/day, which seemed ludicrous to me for what I paid for the room already. (You can, however, find some free Wi-Fi at the Starbucks Coffee in the hotel lobby, so watch for that.) Parking is ample, but they charge $15.00/day for that, too. And don't be surprised if you have to pay more than $10 for a bagel with a nice spread on it! The hotel has several eating establishments in it, but they can be quite expensive. You'll not find much else to eat nearby, but the hotel is only about a 5-7 minutes drive or taxi ride to Old San Juan with many great restaurants.  
<Date>May 6, 2006

<Author>TallahasseeLassi
<Content>Beware - Total Rip-Off and the Worst Hilton Stayed at the Caribe Hilton for business for the SAA convention for a week, at the Government rate. The property is confusing - upon checking in they didn't tell me there was a difference between the main building and tower rooms, so exhausted after flying in, went up and down the wrong elevators dragging my suitcases trying to find my room...My oceanview room in the tower had a view of an ugly building roof, with a small glimpse of the ocean in horizon. When I went to open up the sliding glass door, the handle fell off the door. When I went to call for service, the phones didn't work. After complaining, they moved me to the main building, which had a view of the ocean and fort, and was acceptable, though the bathroom is small.Room service was prompt, fairly priced and acceptable (a veggie burger for $10). Here are where the problems begin...my keys deactivated 4 times - twice in one day, once when I was hand-carryying the key to the pool. I had to wait on a long line to renew my keys four times - and the manager insinuated that I didn't understand how to use my key correctly! They finally switched the lock out, but maintaned that it was my fault for deactivating keys. They comped me a free lunch which was nice - the seafood buffet was excellent - very, very good hotel food.Upon checking out I learned about all the hidden fees. I was chared an extra $19.50 resort fee for each day. When I asked about it and told them I hadn't agrees to it, they said it was impossible to take it off. I've since been dealing with Hilton corporate, who still maintain they can't take the charges off. They claim the charges cover the coffee in the room, access to the beach and pool, a local newspaper, and access to the fitness center. Last time I chacked, these were standard ameneties at all hotels! This hotel will nickel and dime you to death. There are additional charges for practially everything. I'm suprised they didn't charge us for ice. The service was mixed - sometimes we had the most freindly, professional service, and other times, we were made to feel like an imposition to the hotel. There is not much around the hotel - so it is a $10 cab ride each way into Old San Juan. I'd stay there - I've stayed at Hotel Milano and Westin - at least you can get out and walk there. And plus, they don't charge you extra for a packet of coffee in your room, a .25 local paper, and access to their gym. Caribe Hilton - what a rip off!  
<Date>May 4, 2006

<Author>Bob_Kopperl
<Content>Great location, but check the bill before check-out! I recently stayed at the Caribe Hilton for a large conference, and all in all I was pleased with the room, the facilities, and the staff. My only complaint was a mistake on the billing when I tried to separate the room charges from the food and drink billed to the room during my stay. They put both charges on the wrong card, resulting in my checking account being overdrawn. I'm still waiting to get it corrected over the phone, as their computer has been down for a bit. That detail aside, the time I spent there was as good as I hoped for and better than I expected given the mix of reviews. I stayed in the main tower, the closest to the lobby. I saw the rooms of colleagues in the other two towers, and I understood some of the reviews. They look adequate but a little older and worn. For the money spent, try to get a room in the main tower. The food and drink are good but a bit pricey, except for the breakfast buffet which is actually a pretty good bargain and a great spread. Both the Condado and Old San Juan are a healthy, but not too strenuous, walk from the hotel and worth the effort. I heard rumor of the walk to Old San Juan from the Hilton being unsafe, but I found myself much more frightened during a ride in an unofficial taxi back to the hotel from Old SJ.  
<Date>May 3, 2006

<Author>Crystal152
<Content>Beautiful Grounds, Great Pool, Would stay here again !! I stayed at the Caribe Hilton for 4 nights (April 22-April 26). I was very concerned because of the several negative comments I had read. Me and my fiance' will not settle for average standards in a hotel or resort whether traveling in the states or abroad. Our experience at the Caribe Hilton was Great and we will certainly stay here again.The check-in process was rather quick and we were able to take advantage of the Executive Lounge on the 9th floor which provided free breakfast, cocktails and snacks and nightly desert. This was a definate benefit and the quality of food and drinks were superb. The view from the 9th floor lounge was amazing.Our room was a standard room on the 8th floor. Beautiful view and comfortable beds. The bathroom was a little small, however, we didnt spend much time in there! The lobby in the hotel was open to the ocean and displayed a beautiful view of the pool and ocean. The property grounds were beautiful and comparable to a Sandals resort. I loved the 3 tiered pool with small waterfalls. Plenty of spaces for families and couples alike to find a perfect spot. The ocean cove area was very nice and clean. I prefer the pool so only spent time walking there however people were snorkeling only 30' or so from the beach. I can't say enough about the property....I walked the entire grounds daily and enjoyed it all.There were several places to eat, some were pricey, but hey, you are on vacation ! The Olas Health Bar Cafe was my favorite place to eat for lunch...wonderful wraps and salads. Just a short walk over to the spa and workout area and this is a super place to grab lunch and take back to the pool area to eat. After I discovered the Olas Health Bar, I ate there every day even when my fiance' choose a burger from the Atlantico Pool Bar  Grill !! Must try one of the dee-lish wraps here.Overall, the staff was helpful, and friendly, I will agree that the pool services was slow, but it just made me get up and go to the pool bar for my own pina coladas which was no big deal. Note, when ordering a pina colada (this is the place where they were originated) ask for extra spiced rum on top. Yumm !This place overall is somewhere I would return to again. And, we plan to very soon. Please do not listen to all the negative reviews. I give this resort a 4 out of 5.  
<Date>May 2, 2006

<Author>MordySacramento
<Content>Lame destination for vacation and overpriced at $265/night The Caribe Hilton is fine if you're on a business trip but I would recommend against staying there on vacation unless you like so-so accommodations surrounded by construction. We arrived early but we're checked in without incident. However, we were in the Condado Lagoon Villas which is quite a hike from the main lobby.The room itself was OK although we did not need the kitchen, fridge, etc. The bathroom needed to be overhauled and was very small. It felt as if we were in someone's timeshare instead of a hotel.The ground themselves are OK. Some of the buildings definitely could use repair and/or update. The beach is just OK. The 10% resort fee is a joke as it's not close to being a resort.I'd stay there if on business but definitely not for a vacation. There's nothing really close to it except for freeways and construction sites. It's $10 cab ride each way to Old San Juan which was interesting but overhyped.Head somewhere else in the Caribbean!
